Fixed ya variable size window se subarray/substring problems solve karo

3 Problems
ðŸ“š Problem #12

Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock

Sabse sasta kharido, sabse mehnga becho â€” maximum profit kamao! ðŸ’°ðŸ“ˆ

ðŸŸ¢ Easy Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek array prices diya gaya hai jahan prices[i] ek stock ka price hai i-th day pe. Tumhe ek din stock kharidna hai aur future mein kisi din bechna hai. Maximum profit return karo. Agar koi profit nahi ban sakta toh 0 return karo.

ðŸŽ¯ Rule: Pehle BUY, phir SELL! (Time travel allowed nahi hai ðŸ˜„)
ðŸŽ¯ Ek hi transaction: Sirf ek baar buy aur ek baar sell kar sakte ho

Example 1:

prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]

Output: 5

Explanation: Day 2 pe kharido (price=1), Day 5 pe becho (price=6) â†’ Profit = 6-1 = 5

Example 2:

prices = [7, 6, 4, 3, 1]

Output: 0

Explanation: Prices sirf gir rahe hain â€” koi profit nahi, toh 0 return karo

ðŸ“Š Visual Representation

prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]

Price
  7 |  â—
  6 |                 â—        â† SELL here (Day 5)
  5 |        â—
  4 |                       â—
  3 |              â—
  2 |  
  1 |     â—                    â† BUY here (Day 2)
    â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
      0   1   2   3   4   5   Day
      
    Profit = 6 - 1 = 5 ðŸ’°
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse seedha tarika â€” har possible buy-sell pair try karo! ðŸ”

Har din sochte hain "Agar aaj kharida, toh future mein kis din bechne se maximum profit milega?" Sab profits mein se sabse bada return karo.

ðŸ’­ Jaise stock market mein time machine hoti â€” har din jaake check karo future prices!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: maxProfit = 0
2
Outer Loop (Buy Day): i = 0 to n-1
3
Inner Loop (Sell Day): j = i+1 to n-1 (future days only!)
4
Calculate: profit = prices[j] - prices[i]
5
Update: maxProfit = max(maxProfit, profit)

Python Code

def maxProfit(prices):
    maxP = 0
    n = len(prices)
    
    # Har buy day try karo
    for i in range(n):
        buy = prices[i]
        
        # Future mein har sell day try karo
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            sell = prices[j]
            profit = sell - buy
            maxP = max(maxP, profit)
    
    return maxP

# Example
prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]
print(maxProfit(prices))  # Output: 5

Dry Run

Input: prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]

Buy (i)Sell (j)Buy PriceSell PriceProfitmaxP
0171-60
0476-10
121544
141655 âœ…
245615

Final Answer: 5

â±ï¸ Time: O(nÂ²)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)
2

Two Pointers Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Do pointers use karo â€” left = buy day, right = sell day. ðŸ“

Key Idea:

  • Agar prices[right] > prices[left] â†’ Profit ho sakta hai! Calculate karo.
  • Agar prices[right] < prices[left] â†’ Arey! Chhota price mila! Left ko right pe le aao â€” better buying opportunity!
  • Right hamesha aage badhta hai
ðŸ’­ Socho: Tum shop pe ho. Jab tak price badh raha hai, profit track karo. Jab aur sasta mile, wahi naya buy point ban jaaye!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: left = 0 (buy), right = 1 (sell), maxP = 0
2
While right < n:
3
If prices[left] < prices[right]: Calculate profit, update maxP
4
Else: left = right (found cheaper buy price!)
5
right += 1 (always move sell pointer)

Python Code

def maxProfit(prices):
    left = 0   # Buy pointer
    right = 1  # Sell pointer
    maxP = 0
    
    while right < len(prices):
        # Kya profit ho sakta hai?
        if prices[left] < prices[right]:
            profit = prices[right] - prices[left]
            maxP = max(maxP, profit)
        else:
            # Aur sasta mila! Naya buy point
            left = right
        
        right += 1
    
    return maxP

# Example
prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]
print(maxProfit(prices))  # Output: 5

Detailed Dry Run

Input: prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]

Stepleftrightp[L]p[R]ConditionActionmaxP
101717 > 1left = 10
212151 < 5 âœ“profit = 44
313131 < 3 âœ“profit = 24
414161 < 6 âœ“profit = 55 â­
515141 < 4 âœ“profit = 35

right=6, loop ends. Answer: 5 âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)
3

DP Approach (Track Minimum) âœ¨ CLEANEST

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Aur bhi simple approach! Sirf do cheezein track karo: ðŸŽ¯

  • minBuy = Ab tak ka sabse sasta price (best day to buy)
  • maxProfit = Ab tak ka maximum profit

Har din socho: "Agar aaj bechun, aur pehle ke sabse saste din kharida hota, toh kitna profit?"

ðŸ’­ Jaise tum har din stock price dekhte ho aur yaad rakhte ho "ab tak ka lowest kya tha" â€” bas wahi concept!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: minBuy = prices[0], maxP = 0
2
Loop through each price:
3
Calculate: profit = currentPrice - minBuy
4
Update: maxP = max(maxP, profit)
5
Update: minBuy = min(minBuy, currentPrice)

Python Code

def maxProfit(prices):
    minBuy = prices[0]  # Sabse sasta ab tak
    maxP = 0            # Maximum profit ab tak
    
    for price in prices:
        # Agar aaj bechun toh kitna profit?
        profit = price - minBuy
        maxP = max(maxP, profit)
        
        # Kya aaj aur sasta hai? Update karo
        minBuy = min(minBuy, price)
    
    return maxP

# Example
prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]
print(maxProfit(prices))  # Output: 5

Detailed Dry Run

Input: prices = [7, 1, 5, 3, 6, 4]

DayPriceminBuy (before)ProfitmaxPminBuy (after)
077007
117-6â†’001 ðŸ”½
251441
331241
46155 â­1
541351

Final Answer: 5 âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)

âš ï¸ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

âŒ

Pehle Sell, Phir Buy (Time Travel!)

Galti se j < i use karna â€” matlab past mein bech rahe ho. Invalid!

# WRONG âŒ
for i in range(len(prices)):
    for j in range(i):  # j < i = past!
        profit = prices[j] - prices[i]
âœ… Fix: j hamesha i+1 se start ho (future days)
âŒ

Negative Profit Return Karna

Agar prices sirf gir rahe hain toh profit = 0 hona chahiye, negative nahi!

# WRONG âŒ
return maxPrice - minPrice  
# Agar maxPrice pehle aaya toh negative!
âœ… Fix: maxP = 0 se start karo, negative kabhi store mat karo
âŒ

Min aur Max Alag Track Karna

Overall min aur max find karke subtract karna GALAT hai â€” min ke baad max aana chahiye!

âœ… Fix: Order matter karta hai â€” buy BEFORE sell!

ðŸ“‹ Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force O(nÂ²) O(1) Har pair check â€” slow
Two Pointers O(n) O(1) Sliding window style
DP (Track Min) BEST O(n) O(1) Sabse clean & simple âš¡
ðŸ“Œ Key Insight: Har din socho "Ab tak ka sabse sasta kya tha?" Agar aaj bechun toh profit = today - minSoFar. Bas itna simple! ðŸ’°
ðŸ“š Problem #13

Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters

Bina repeat wala sabse lamba substring dhundho â€” Sliding Window ka classic! ðŸªŸ

ðŸŸ¡ Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek string s di gayi hai. Tumhe sabse lamba substring dhundna hai jismein koi bhi character repeat na ho. Us substring ki length return karo.

ðŸŽ¯ Substring vs Subsequence: Substring = continuous characters, Subsequence = skip kar sakte ho
ðŸŽ¯ Example: "abc" substring hai "xabc" ka, but "ac" subsequence hai (substring nahi)

Example 1:

s = "abcabcbb"

Output: 3

Explanation: "abc" sabse lamba hai bina repeat ke (length = 3)

Example 2:

s = "bbbbb"

Output: 1

Explanation: Sab same hai, toh sirf "b" = length 1

Example 3:

s = "pwwkew"

Output: 3

Explanation: "wke" ya "kew" dono valid hain (length = 3)

ðŸŽ­ Real-life Analogy â€” VIP Guest List!

Scenario: Socho tum ek exclusive party ke bouncer ho. ðŸšª Party mein sirf unique naam wale log allowed hain â€” agar same naam wala dobara aaye toh pichle wale ko nikaalte jao jab tak duplicate na nikal jaaye!

Sliding Window: Tumhari party room ek "window" hai. Naya guest aaya (right move) â†’ room mein add karo. Duplicate aaya? Darwaze se (left se) logo ko nikaalte jao jab tak duplicate na nikal jaaye! ðŸš¶â€â™‚ï¸âž¡ï¸

Track karo: Har waqt party mein kitne unique guests hain â€” wo tumhara current window size hai. Maximum track karo â€” yahi answer hai! ðŸŽ‰

ðŸ’¡ Sliding Window Pattern: Jab bhi problem mein "longest/shortest subarray/substring with some condition" ho â€” Sliding Window try karo! Two pointers (left, right) use karo jo expand aur shrink karte hain! ðŸªŸ

ðŸŽ¤ Interview Tips â€” Sliding Window Master Bano!

  • ðŸªŸ Pattern recognize karo: "Yeh longest substring problem hai with a constraint (no repeats). Classic sliding window!"
  • ðŸ”„ Two approaches batao: "Set se ek-ek karke shrink kar sakte hain, ya HashMap se directly jump kar sakte hain â€” HashMap optimal hai!"
  • ðŸ“ Window boundaries explain karo: "left aur right pointers mera current valid window define karte hain. Right expand karta hai, left shrink karta hai jab constraint violate ho"
  • âš ï¸ Edge cases cover karo:
    â€¢ Empty string â†’ 0
    â€¢ All unique "abcd" â†’ length = n (whole string)
    â€¢ All same "aaaa" â†’ 1
    â€¢ Special characters/spaces count hain!
  • ðŸ’¡ HashMap optimization batao: "HashMap mein last seen index store karke left pointer seedha jump kar sakta hai, ek-ek remove karne ki zaroorat nahi!"

ðŸ§  Kyun Sliding Window Kaam Karta Hai? â€” Deep Understanding!

Key Insight: Agar current window [left, right] mein duplicate aa gaya, toh left se chhote index kisi kaam ke nahi!

Kyun? Socho "abcb" mein jab second 'b' aaya (index 3):
â€¢ Window [0,2] = "abc" valid tha
â€¢ Ab 'b' aaya jo index 1 pe bhi hai
â€¢ Kya starting index 0 se koi better answer milega? Nahi! ðŸš«
â€¢ Kyunki "abcb" mein 'b' do jagah hai â€” left ko aage badhana padega!

Optimization: Instead of ek-ek hatana, seedha duplicate ke next position pe jump karo! Isliye HashMap mein index store karte hain! ðŸš€

â“ Common Follow-up Questions â€” Ready Raho!

Q1: "At most K distinct characters allowed ho toh?" (Longest Substring with At Most K Distinct)
â†’ HashMap mein character frequency track karo. Jab distinct > K, shrink karo!

Q2: "At most 2 distinct characters?"
â†’ Same approach, K=2. Fruits into baskets problem bhi same hai!

Q3: "Smallest window jo saare unique characters contain kare?"
â†’ Minimum Window Substring variant. Shrink jab valid ho, expand jab invalid!

Q4: "Agar string mein sirf lowercase letters hon toh optimize?"
â†’ HashMap ki jagah size-26 array use kar sakte ho â€” constant space!

ðŸªŸ Sliding Window Visualization

s = "abcabcbb"

Step 1: [a] b c a b c b b     â†’ window = "a", length = 1
Step 2: [a b] c a b c b b     â†’ window = "ab", length = 2  
Step 3: [a b c] a b c b b     â†’ window = "abc", length = 3 â­
Step 4:  a [b c a] b c b b    â†’ 'a' repeat! shrink left, window = "bca", length = 3
Step 5:  a b [c a b] c b b    â†’ 'b' repeat! shrink, window = "cab", length = 3
Step 6:  a b c [a b c] b b    â†’ 'c' repeat! shrink, window = "abc", length = 3
Step 7:  a b c a [b c b] b    â†’ 'b' repeat! shrink, window = "cb", length = 2
Step 8:  a b c a b c [b] b    â†’ 'b' repeat! shrink, window = "b", length = 1

Maximum Length Found: 3 âœ…
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Har possible starting position se try karo! ðŸ”

Har index se shuru karke substring badhate jao jab tak duplicate na mile. Set use karo characters track karne ke liye. Duplicate mila? Ruk jao, length note karo, next starting point pe jao.

ðŸ’­ Jaise har ghar se nikal ke road pe chalo jab tak signal (duplicate) na mile â€” sabse lambi road win!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: maxLen = 0
2
Outer Loop: Har starting index i ke liye
3
Create Set: charSet = {} for tracking
4
Inner Loop: j = i to n-1, agar s[j] set mein hai â†’ break
5
Update: maxLen = max(maxLen, len(charSet))

Python Code

def lengthOfLongestSubstring(s):
    maxLen = 0
    
    # Har starting position try karo
    for i in range(len(s)):
        charSet = set()
        
        # Extend karo jab tak duplicate na mile
        for j in range(i, len(s)):
            if s[j] in charSet:
                break  # Duplicate mila, ruko!
            charSet.add(s[j])
        
        maxLen = max(maxLen, len(charSet))
    
    return maxLen

# Example
s = "abcabcbb"
print(lengthOfLongestSubstring(s))  # Output: 3
â±ï¸ Time: O(n Ã— m)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(m)

* n = string length, m = unique characters (max 26 for lowercase)

2

Sliding Window with Set

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Ek window maintain karo jo hamesha valid ho (no duplicates)! ðŸªŸ

  • Right pointer (r) â†’ Window expand karta hai
  • Left pointer (l) â†’ Duplicate aaye toh shrink karta hai
  • Set â†’ Current window ke characters track karta hai

Jab s[r] already set mein ho, left se characters hatate jao jab tak duplicate na nikal jaaye!

ðŸ’­ Jaise AC room mein zyada log aa gaye toh darwaze se bahar nikalo jab tak space na ban jaaye!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: charSet = {}, left = 0, maxLen = 0
2
Expand: right pointer 0 se n-1 tak move karo
3
Shrink: Jab tak s[right] set mein hai â†’ s[left] remove karo, left++
4
Add: s[right] set mein add karo
5
Update: maxLen = max(maxLen, right - left + 1)

Python Code

def lengthOfLongestSubstring(s):
    charSet = set()
    left = 0
    maxLen = 0
    
    for right in range(len(s)):
        # Duplicate hai? Left se hatao jab tak valid na ho
        while s[right] in charSet:
            charSet.remove(s[left])
            left += 1
        
        # Ab safe hai, add karo
        charSet.add(s[right])
        
        # Window size track karo
        maxLen = max(maxLen, right - left + 1)
    
    return maxLen

# Example
s = "abcabcbb"
print(lengthOfLongestSubstring(s))  # Output: 3

Detailed Dry Run

Input: s = "abcabcbb"

rs[r]Set BeforeShrink?Set AfterlWindowmaxLen
0a{}No{a}0"a"1
1b{a}No{a,b}0"ab"2
2c{a,b}No{a,b,c}0"abc"3 â­
3a{a,b,c}Yes! remove a{b,c,a}1"bca"3
4b{b,c,a}Yes! remove b{c,a,b}2"cab"3
5c{c,a,b}Yes! remove c{a,b,c}3"abc"3
6b{a,b,c}Yes! remove a,b{c,b}5"cb"3
7b{c,b}Yes! remove c,b{b}7"b"3

Final Answer: 3 âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(m)
3

Sliding Window with HashMap âœ¨ OPTIMAL

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Set wale approach mein left pointer ek-ek karke move hota hai. HashMap use karke directly jump kar sakte hain! ðŸš€

Idea: Har character ka last seen index store karo. Jab duplicate mile, left pointer ko seedha us index + 1 pe le jao!

ðŸ’­ Jaise GPS shortcut batata hai â€” ek-ek gali traverse karne ki jagah seedha destination pe jump!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: charIndex = {} (char â†’ last index), left = 0, maxLen = 0
2
Loop: right pointer 0 se n-1 tak
3
Check: Agar s[right] map mein hai aur index >= left
4
Jump: left = charIndex[s[right]] + 1
5
Update: charIndex[s[right]] = right, maxLen = max(...)

Python Code

# ============================================
# âœ¨ SLIDING WINDOW + HASHMAP: Optimal Solution
# ============================================
# HashMap mein store karo: character â†’ last seen index
# Duplicate mile toh DIRECTLY JUMP karo left pointer!
# No need to remove one-by-one like Set approach ðŸš€

def lengthOfLongestSubstring(s):
    """
    Optimal Sliding Window with HashMap
    
    ðŸ’¡ Key Insight:
    - HashMap stores LAST SEEN INDEX of each character
    - Jab duplicate mile, left pointer seedha jump karega
    - O(n) time with O(n) space
    """
    
    # ðŸ—ºï¸ HashMap: character â†’ last index jahan dekha
    charIndex = {}
    
    # ðŸ“ Left pointer of window
    left = 0
    
    # ðŸ“ Maximum length found
    maxLen = 0
    
    # ðŸ”„ Right pointer traverse karega string
    for right in range(len(s)):
        char = s[right]
        
        # ðŸ” Kya yeh character pehle dekha hai CURRENT WINDOW ke andar?
        if char in charIndex and charIndex[char] >= left:
            # âœ… Duplicate found inside window!
            # ðŸš€ DIRECT JUMP: Left ko duplicate ke AAGE le jao
            left = charIndex[char] + 1
        
        # ðŸ“ Update: Current character ka last seen index
        charIndex[char] = right
        
        # ðŸ“ Window size calculate karo aur max update karo
        windowSize = right - left + 1
        maxLen = max(maxLen, windowSize)
    
    return maxLen


# ðŸ§ª Testing
print(lengthOfLongestSubstring("abcabcbb"))  # Output: 3 ("abc")
print(lengthOfLongestSubstring("bbbbb"))     # Output: 1 ("b")
print(lengthOfLongestSubstring("pwwkew"))    # Output: 3 ("wke")
print(lengthOfLongestSubstring(""))          # Output: 0 (empty)
print(lengthOfLongestSubstring("abba"))      # Output: 2 ("ab" or "ba")

Why max(left, index+1)?

âš ï¸ Important: Kabhi kabhi duplicate character window ke bahar ho sakta hai (left se pehle). Us case mein left ko peeche nahi le jaana!
Example: "abba" mein jab second 'a' aaye, pehla 'a' already window se bahar hai. 
# Safe version with max()
if char in charIndex:
    left = max(left, charIndex[char] + 1)  # Kabhi peeche mat jao!
â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(m)

âš ï¸ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

âŒ

Left Pointer Peeche Le Jaana

HashMap approach mein left = charIndex[char] + 1 use karte waqt max() bhool jaana!

# WRONG âŒ
left = charIndex[char] + 1  # Peeche ja sakta hai!

# RIGHT âœ…  
left = max(left, charIndex[char] + 1)
âŒ

Index Update Bhool Jaana

Har character ke liye charIndex[char] = right update karna zaroori hai â€” duplicate ho ya naya!

âœ… Fix: Loop ke end mein hamesha index update karo
âŒ

Window Size Calculation

right - left + 1 hona chahiye, sirf right - left nahi! Dono ends inclusive hain.

âœ… Fix: Window [left, right] inclusive â†’ size = right - left + 1

ðŸ“‹ Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force O(n Ã— m) O(m) Har position se try
Sliding Window + Set O(n) O(m) Ek-ek shrink
Sliding Window + HashMap BEST O(n) O(m) Direct jump âš¡
ðŸ“Œ Key Pattern: Sliding Window = Two Pointers + Valid Window Condition. Expand karo (right++), Invalid ho toh Shrink karo (left++). Yaad rakho! ðŸªŸ
ðŸ“š Problem #14

Longest Repeating Character Replacement

K replacements allowed â€” sabse lamba same-character substring banao! ðŸ”„

ðŸŸ¡ Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek string s di gayi hai (sirf uppercase letters) aur ek integer k. Tum string mein maximum k characters replace kar sakte ho kisi bhi doosre character se. Replace karne ke baad sabse lamba substring dhundho jismein sab characters same hon.

ðŸŽ¯ Goal: Maximum length substring jahan sab letters same hon (k replacements use karke)
ðŸŽ¯ Trick: Window mein jo character sabse zyada hai, baaki sab replace kar do!

Example 1:

s = "ABAB", k = 2

Output: 4

Explanation: Dono 'A' ko 'B' se replace karo â†’ "BBBB" (ya 'B' ko 'A' se â†’ "AAAA")

Example 2:

s = "AABABBA", k = 1

Output: 4

Explanation: "AABA" mein middle 'B' replace karo â†’ "AAAA" (length = 4)

ðŸªŸ Key Insight Visualization

s = "AABABBA", k = 1

Window Valid Condition:
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  Window Size - Most Frequent Char Count â‰¤ k        â”‚
â”‚                                                     â”‚
â”‚  Matlab: Kitne characters replace karne hain?      â”‚
â”‚         = Total - Sabse zyada wala                 â”‚
â”‚         â‰¤ k hona chahiye!                          â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Example: Window = "AABA" (size = 4)
- A appears 3 times (most frequent)
- Replace needed = 4 - 3 = 1 â‰¤ k(1) âœ… Valid!

Example: Window = "AABAB" (size = 5)  
- A appears 3 times
- Replace needed = 5 - 3 = 2 > k(1) âŒ Invalid!
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Har possible starting position se try karo! ðŸ”

Har index se shuru karke window badhao. Har window ke liye check karo: window_size - max_frequency â‰¤ k? Agar haan, toh valid hai!

ðŸ’­ Jaise har classroom mein jaake count karo â€” kitne students same dress mein hain? Baaki ko uniform dena hai!

Python Code

def characterReplacement(s, k):
    maxLen = 0
    
    for i in range(len(s)):
        count = {}  # Character frequency
        maxFreq = 0  # Most frequent char count
        
        for j in range(i, len(s)):
            # Update frequency
            count[s[j]] = count.get(s[j], 0) + 1
            maxFreq = max(maxFreq, count[s[j]])
            
            windowSize = j - i + 1
            replacementsNeeded = windowSize - maxFreq
            
            # Valid window?
            if replacementsNeeded <= k:
                maxLen = max(maxLen, windowSize)
        
    return maxLen

# Example
print(characterReplacement("AABABBA", 1))  # Output: 4
â±ï¸ Time: O(nÂ²)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(26) = O(1)
2

Sliding Window (Per Character)

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Ek target character fix karo (A se Z tak try karo)! ðŸŽ¯

Har character ke liye socho: "Agar main poora window isi character ka banana chahun, toh kitne replace karne padenge?"

  • Window mein count karo target character kitni baar hai
  • Baaki sab replace karne hain = windowSize - targetCount
  • Agar replacements > k â†’ shrink karo
ðŸ’­ Jaise decide karo "Sabko red shirt deni hai" â€” count karo kitne already red mein hain, baaki ko change karna padega!

Python Code

def characterReplacement(s, k):
    maxLen = 0
    uniqueChars = set(s)  # All unique characters
    
    # Try making window of each character
    for targetChar in uniqueChars:
        left = 0
        targetCount = 0  # Count of target char in window
        
        for right in range(len(s)):
            if s[right] == targetChar:
                targetCount += 1
            
            # Window invalid? Shrink!
            while (right - left + 1) - targetCount > k:
                if s[left] == targetChar:
                    targetCount -= 1
                left += 1
            
            maxLen = max(maxLen, right - left + 1)
    
    return maxLen

# Example
print(characterReplacement("AABABBA", 1))  # Output: 4
â±ï¸ Time: O(26 Ã— n) = O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(26) = O(1)
3

Sliding Window (Optimal) âœ¨ OPTIMAL

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Ek hi pass mein solve karo! Key insight: ðŸš€

Window valid hai agar: windowSize - maxFrequency â‰¤ k

  • maxFrequency = Window mein sabse zyada baar aane wala character
  • Baaki sab characters replace karne hain
  • Agar replace count > k â†’ window shrink karo
ðŸ’¡ Trick: maxFrequency ko decrease nahi karte jab window shrink karte hain! Kyun? Kyunki hum longest dhund rahe hain â€” agar pehle bada maxFreq tha, wahi best case hai. Chhota window consider karna bekar hai!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: count = {}, left = 0, maxFreq = 0, maxLen = 0
2
Expand: right pointer move karo, count[s[right]]++
3
Update maxFreq: maxFreq = max(maxFreq, count[s[right]])
4
Check Valid: Agar windowSize - maxFreq > k â†’ shrink (left++)
5
Update Answer: maxLen = max(maxLen, windowSize)

Python Code

# ============================================
# âœ¨ OPTIMAL: Single Pass Sliding Window
# ============================================
# Key Formula: windowSize - maxFrequency â‰¤ k
# 
# ðŸ’¡ Logic:
# - Window mein sabse zyada baar aane wala character rakh lo
# - Baaki sab replace kar do
# - Agar replacement count > k â†’ window invalid â†’ shrink!

def characterReplacement(s, k):
    """
    Optimal Sliding Window â€” O(n) time!
    
    ðŸŽ¯ Window Valid Condition:
    (windowSize - maxFrequency) â‰¤ k
    
    Matlab: Kitne characters replace karne hain?
    = Total characters - Sabse frequent character
    = Yeh k se kam ya equal hona chahiye!
    """
    
    # ðŸ“Š Character frequency count in current window
    count = {}
    
    # ðŸ”¥ Maximum frequency of any character in window
    # âš ï¸ Important: Yeh decrease NAHI karte shrink pe!
    maxFreq = 0
    
    # ðŸ“ Answer: Maximum valid window length
    maxLen = 0
    
    # ðŸ“ Left pointer of window
    left = 0
    
    # ðŸ”„ Right pointer expands the window
    for right in range(len(s)):
        
        # âž• Add current character to window
        char = s[right]
        count[char] = count.get(char, 0) + 1
        
        # ðŸ“ˆ Update max frequency (only increases!)
        maxFreq = max(maxFreq, count[char])
        
        # ðŸ“ Current window size
        windowSize = right - left + 1
        
        # âŒ Window INVALID? (need more than k replacements)
        # Shrink from left until valid!
        while windowSize - maxFreq > k:
            # Remove leftmost character
            count[s[left]] -= 1
            left += 1
            windowSize -= 1
        
        # âœ… Valid window â€” update answer!
        maxLen = max(maxLen, windowSize)
    
    return maxLen


# ðŸ§ª Testing
print(characterReplacement("ABAB", 2))     # Output: 4 (AAAA or BBBB)
print(characterReplacement("AABABBA", 1))  # Output: 4 (AABA â†’ AAAA)
print(characterReplacement("AAAA", 2))     # Output: 4 (already same)
print(characterReplacement("ABCD", 1))     # Output: 2 (any 2 adjacent)

Detailed Dry Run

Input: s = "AABABBA", k = 1

rs[r]countmaxFreqwindowSizereplacevalid?lmaxLen
0A{A:1}110âœ…01
1A{A:2}220âœ…02
2B{A:2,B:1}231âœ…03
3A{A:3,B:1}341âœ…04 â­
4B{A:3,B:2}352âŒâ†’shrink14
5B{A:2,B:3}352âŒâ†’shrink24
6A{A:2,B:3}352âŒâ†’shrink34

Final Answer: 4 âœ…

Kyun maxFreq Decrease Nahi Karte?

ðŸ¤” Common Question: Jab window shrink karte hain, maxFreq update kyun nahi karte?

Answer: Kyunki hum longest dhund rahe hain!
  • Agar pehle maxFreq = 3 tha aur window valid thi
  • Ab maxFreq kam ho gaya, toh window bhi chhoti hogi
  • Chhoti window se answer update nahi hoga anyway!
  • Stale maxFreq sirf window ko zyada strict banata hai â€” galat answer nahi deta
â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(26) = O(1)

âš ï¸ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

âŒ

maxFreq Recalculate Karna

Har baar shrink ke baad maxFreq recalculate karna unnecessary hai aur complexity badha deta hai.

âœ… Fix: maxFreq ko stale rehne do â€” answer pe effect nahi padta!
âŒ

Window Size Galat Calculate

right - left + 1 hona chahiye! Off-by-one error se validity check galat ho jaata hai.

âœ… Fix: [left, right] inclusive â†’ size = right - left + 1
âŒ

Shrink Mein Count Update Bhoolna

Left pointer move karte waqt count[s[left]]-- karna mat bhoolna!

âœ… Fix: Pehle count update, phir left++

ðŸ“‹ Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force O(nÂ²) O(1) Har substring check
Per Character O(26n) O(1) 26 passes, simple logic
Single Pass BEST O(n) O(1) Track maxFreq âš¡
ðŸ“Œ Key Formula: windowSize - maxFrequency â‰¤ k â†’ Valid window! Sabse frequent character ko target maan lo, baaki sab replace karo. ðŸ”„
ðŸ“š

Stack

LIFO (Last In First Out) â€” Plates ki tarah stack karo!

2 Problems
ðŸ“š Problem #15

Valid Parentheses

Brackets properly match hain ya nahi? Stack ka classic problem! ðŸ¥ž

ðŸŸ¢ Easy Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek string s di gayi hai jismein sirf '(', ')', '{', '}', '[', ']' characters hain. Batao ki string valid hai ya nahi.

ðŸŽ¯ Valid Rules:
1. Open bracket same type ke close bracket se band hona chahiye
2. Sahi order mein band hona chahiye (jo last mein khula, wo pehle band)
3. Har close bracket ke liye ek matching open hona chahiye

Example 1:

s = "()"

Output: true âœ…

Example 2:

s = "()[]{}"

Output: true âœ…

Example 3:

s = "(]"

Output: false âŒ â€” Open '(' but close ']' (mismatch!)

Example 4:

s = "([)]"

Output: false âŒ â€” Wrong order! '[' ke baad ')' aa gaya

ðŸŽ­ Real-life Analogy â€” Nested Boxes Ki Tarah!

Scenario 1 â€” Russian Dolls (Matryoshka): ðŸª†
Socho tumhare paas nested dolls hain â€” chhoti doll badi ke andar. Jab kholte ho, jo last mein band ki thi (sabse bahar wali), wo pehle khulti hai! Ye exactly LIFO (Last In, First Out) hai â€” Stack ka principle!

Scenario 2 â€” Code Editor Mein Brackets: ðŸ’»
Jab tum if (x > 0) { print(arr[i]); } likhte ho, editor automatically check karta hai ki brackets sahi se match ho rahe hain ya nahi. Internally Stack use hota hai!

Scenario 3 â€” Undo Feature: ðŸ”™
Word processor mein Ctrl+Z (Undo) â€” last action first undo hota hai! Stack based!

ðŸ’¡ Key Pattern: Jab bhi "nested structure" ho ya "last operation first reverse" karna ho â€” Stack sochna! Parentheses, HTML tags, function calls, undo â€” sab Stack problems hain! ðŸ¥ž

ðŸŽ¤ Interview Tips â€” Stack Problems Ka King Hai Ye!

  • ðŸ“š Stack basics explain karo: "Stack LIFO hai â€” Last In, First Out. Plates ki tarah â€” jo upar rakhi, wo pehle nikaalte ho!"
  • ðŸ—ºï¸ Mapping logic batao: "Main ek HashMap banaunga jo closeâ†’open mapping store karega. Close bracket aaye toh check karunga ki top pe matching open hai ya nahi"
  • âš ï¸ Edge cases mention karo:
    â€¢ Empty string â†’ true (koi mismatch nahi)
    â€¢ Odd length â†’ false (pairs ban nahi sakte)
    â€¢ Sirf opening brackets "((" â†’ false (close nahi hue)
    â€¢ Sirf closing brackets "))" â†’ false (kuch khula hi nahi)
  • ðŸ§  Stack empty check mat bhoolo: "Jab close bracket aaye aur stack empty ho, toh invalid hai â€” kuch khula hi nahi jo band karein!"

ðŸ§  Kyun Stack Perfect Hai Is Problem Ke Liye?

Valid parentheses ka fundamental rule hai: "Jo bracket last mein khula, wo pehle band hona chahiye!"

Example: {[()]}
â€¢ { khula first
â€¢ [ khula second
â€¢ ( khula third (LAST)
â€¢ ) band karta hai ( ko (LAST opened = FIRST closed) âœ…
â€¢ ] band karta hai [ ko âœ…
â€¢ } band karta hai { ko (FIRST opened = LAST closed) âœ…

Ye exactly LIFO order hai! Stack naturally is order ko maintain karta hai! ðŸŽ¯

â“ Common Follow-up Questions â€” Ye Bhi Pooch Sakte Hain!

Q1: "Agar wildcard '*' ho jo koi bhi bracket represent kar sake?"
â†’ DP ya Greedy approach lagega. Hard level problem ban jaati hai!

Q2: "Minimum brackets remove karne ho taaki valid ban jaye?"
â†’ Stack se track karo konse unmatched hain, unhe remove karo. BFS bhi use ho sakta hai!

Q3: "Longest valid parentheses substring dhundhna ho?"
â†’ Stack with indices use karo ya DP. LeetCode Hard problem hai ye!

Q4: "Generate all valid parentheses combinations of length n?"
â†’ Backtracking! Open count aur close count track karo. Classic recursion problem!

ðŸ¥ž Stack Ka Concept â€” Plates Ki Tarah!

Stack = LIFO (Last In, First Out)
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  Jaise plates stack karte ho:            â”‚
â”‚                                          â”‚
â”‚    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”  â† Last plate = First out       â”‚
â”‚    â”‚ ( â”‚                                 â”‚
â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”¤                                 â”‚
â”‚    â”‚ [ â”‚                                 â”‚
â”‚    â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”¤                                 â”‚
â”‚    â”‚ { â”‚  â† First plate = Last out       â”‚
â”‚    â””â”€â”€â”€â”˜                                 â”‚
â”‚                                          â”‚
â”‚  Opening bracket â†’ Push (stack mein dalo)â”‚
â”‚  Closing bracket â†’ Pop & Check (nikalo)  â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Example: s = "{[()]}"
Step 1: '{' â†’ Push    Stack: [{]
Step 2: '[' â†’ Push    Stack: [{, []
Step 3: '(' â†’ Push    Stack: [{, [, (]
Step 4: ')' â†’ Pop '(' âœ… matches!  Stack: [{, []
Step 5: ']' â†’ Pop '[' âœ… matches!  Stack: [{]
Step 6: '}' â†’ Pop '{' âœ… matches!  Stack: []

Stack empty at end â†’ VALID! âœ…
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Simple idea: Valid string mein matching pairs honge "()", "[]", "{}" ðŸŽ¯

Agar string valid hai, toh ek-ek karke pairs hatate jao. Jab tak "()", "[]", ya "{}" mile, replace karte jao empty string se.

  • Agar end mein string empty ho gayi â†’ Valid!
  • Agar kuch bacha â†’ Invalid!
ðŸ’­ Jaise nested dolls â€” andar wali pehle nikalo, phir bahar wali!

Python Code

# ============================================
# ðŸ”„ BRUTE FORCE: Valid Parentheses Check
# ============================================
# Idea: Valid string mein pairs honge â€” "()", "[]", "{}"
# Ek-ek karke pairs hataate jao jab tak string empty na ho!

def isValid(s):
    """
    Brute Force: Pairs ko replace karte jao
    
    ðŸŽ¯ Logic:
    - Jab tak string mein "()", "[]", ya "{}" mile
    - Replace karo empty string se
    - End mein string empty ho â†’ Valid! âœ…
    
    Time: O(nÂ²) â€” har replace O(n), n/2 iterations
    Space: O(n) â€” string copy banti hai
    """
    
    # Jab tak koi matching pair mile, replace karte raho
    while '()' in s or '{}' in s or '[]' in s:
        s = s.replace('()', '')   # "()" ko hatao
        s = s.replace('{}', '')   # "{}" ko hatao
        s = s.replace('[]', '')   # "[]" ko hatao
    
    # ðŸŽ¯ Agar string empty ho gayi â†’ All pairs matched!
    return s == ''


# ðŸ§ª Testing
print(isValid("()"))         # True âœ…
print(isValid("()[]{}"))     # True âœ…
print(isValid("(]"))         # False âŒ (mismatch)
print(isValid("{[()]}"))     # True âœ… (nested)
print(isValid("(("))         # False âŒ (unmatched)

Dry Run

Input: s = "{[()]}"

IterationStringAction
Start"{[()]}"Find "()"
1"{[]}"Replaced "()" â†’ Find "[]"
2"{}"Replaced "[]" â†’ Find "{}"
3""Replaced "{}" â†’ Empty!

String empty â†’ true âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(nÂ²)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(n)

âš ï¸ Slow kyun? Har replace O(n) leta hai, aur worst case mein n/2 iterations!

2

Stack Approach âœ¨ OPTIMAL

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Valid parentheses follow LIFO order â€” "Jo last mein khula, wo pehle band!" ðŸ¥ž

Yeh exactly Stack ka behavior hai! Plates ki tarah:

  • Opening bracket â†’ Stack mein push karo
  • Closing bracket â†’ Stack se top check karo, matching ho toh pop
  • End mein â†’ Stack empty hona chahiye!
ðŸ’­ Jab close bracket aaye: Check karo â€” kya last wala open bracket match karta hai?
Agar haan â†’ Pop karo. Agar nahi â†’ INVALID!

Algorithm Steps

1
Create mapping: Close â†’ Open mapping banao {')':'(', ']':'[', '}':'{'}
2
Loop: Har character ke liye check karo
3
If Opening: Stack mein push karo
4
If Closing: Stack empty nahi ho aur top match kare â†’ Pop. Else â†’ False
5
Return: Stack empty hai â†’ True, else False

Python Code

# ============================================
# ðŸ¥ž STACK: Valid Parentheses (OPTIMAL Solution)
# ============================================
# Stack = LIFO (Last In, First Out)
# "Jo last mein khula, wo pehle band hona chahiye!"
# 
# ðŸŽ¯ Logic:
# - Opening bracket aaye â†’ Stack mein PUSH karo
# - Closing bracket aaye â†’ Stack se POP karo & MATCH karo
# - End mein Stack empty hona chahiye!

def isValid(s):
    """
    Stack-based approach â€” O(n) time, O(n) space
    
    ðŸ’¡ Why Stack works?
    - Parentheses follow LIFO order
    - Last opened bracket must close first!
    - Exactly like stacking plates ðŸ½ï¸
    """
    
    # ðŸ“š Stack to store opening brackets
    stack = []
    
    # ðŸ—ºï¸ Mapping: Closing â†’ Opening bracket
    # Jab closing mile, check karo ki correct opening thi ya nahi
    closeToOpen = {
        ')': '(',    # ')' ka match '(' hai
        ']': '[',    # ']' ka match '[' hai
        '}': '{'     # '}' ka match '{' hai
    }
    
    # ðŸ”„ Har character ko process karo
    for char in s:
        
        # ðŸ”´ CASE 1: Closing bracket mila
        if char in closeToOpen:
            # Check karo: Stack empty toh nahi? Aur top match karta hai?
            if stack and stack[-1] == closeToOpen[char]:
                # âœ… Match! Pop karo
                stack.pop()
            else:
                # âŒ Mismatch ya stack empty â€” Invalid!
                return False
        
        # ðŸŸ¢ CASE 2: Opening bracket mila
        else:
            # Simply push karo stack mein
            stack.append(char)
    
    # ðŸŽ¯ FINAL CHECK: Stack empty hona chahiye!
    # Agar kuch bacha â†’ unmatched opening brackets
    return len(stack) == 0


# ðŸ§ª Testing All Cases
print(isValid("()"))         # True âœ… â€” Simple pair
print(isValid("()[]{}"))     # True âœ… â€” Multiple pairs
print(isValid("(]"))         # False âŒ â€” Mismatch
print(isValid("{[()]}"))     # True âœ… â€” Nested valid
print(isValid("([)]"))       # False âŒ â€” Wrong order
print(isValid("(("))         # False âŒ â€” Unmatched opens

Detailed Dry Run

Input: s = "([{}])"

icharTypeActionStack
0(OpenPush[(]
1[OpenPush[(, []
2{OpenPush[(, [, {]
3}CloseTop='{' âœ… Pop[(, []
4]CloseTop='[' âœ… Pop[(]
5)CloseTop='(' âœ… Pop[]

Stack empty â†’ true âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(n)

âš ï¸ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

âŒ

Empty Stack Check Bhoolna

Close bracket aaye aur stack empty ho â€” pehle check karo warna crash!

# âŒ WRONG: stack[-1] pehle access karna
if stack[-1] == closeToOpen[c]:

# âœ… CORRECT: Pehle check karo stack empty toh nahi
if stack and stack[-1] == closeToOpen[c]:
âŒ

End Mein Stack Check Bhoolna

"(()" process ho jaata hai bina error ke, but '(' bacha reh jaata hai! End mein stack empty check karo.

âœ… Fix: return len(stack) == 0
âŒ

Mapping Direction Galat

Close â†’ Open hona chahiye, Open â†’ Close nahi!

âœ… Correct: {')': '(', ']': '[', '}': '{'}
âŒ

Queue Use Karna Stack Ki Jagah

Queue FIFO hai, Stack LIFO! Parentheses ko LIFO chahiye (last opened = first closed).

âœ… Fix: Stack use karo â€” list with append() & pop()

ðŸ“‹ Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force (Replace) O(nÂ²) O(n) Pairs replace karte jao
Stack BEST O(n) O(n) LIFO perfect fit! âš¡
ðŸ“Œ Key Insight: Stack = LIFO = "Jo last mein khula, wo pehle band!" Jab bhi nested structure ho (parentheses, HTML tags, function calls), Stack try karo! ðŸ¥ž

25. Min Stack

Stack with getMin() in O(1) â€” Design ka classic interview question! ðŸ“š

MEDIUM

ðŸ“‹ Problem Statement

Design a stack that supports push, pop, top, and retrieving the minimum element in constant time O(1).

Operations:
  • push(val) â€” pushes the element val onto the stack
  • pop() â€” removes the element on the top of the stack
  • top() â€” gets the top element of the stack
  • getMin() â€” retrieves the minimum element in the stack
Example:
MinStack minStack = new MinStack();
minStack.push(-2);
minStack.push(0);
minStack.push(-3);
minStack.getMin();   // return -3
minStack.pop();
minStack.top();      // return 0
minStack.getMin();   // return -2
Constraints:
  • -2Â³Â¹ â‰¤ val â‰¤ 2Â³Â¹ - 1
  • Methods pop, top and getMin will always be called on non-empty stacks
  • At most 3 Ã— 10â´ calls will be made to push, pop, top, and getMin

ðŸ§  Problem Ka Real Intuition â€” Kya Sochna Hai?

ðŸŽ¯ Core Question: Normal stack me getMin() ke liye poora stack scan karna padta hai â€” O(n). Lekin hume chahiye O(1) me minimum! Kaise karein?

ðŸ  Real Life Analogy â€” Book Stack Example

Imagine tumhare paas books ka stack hai. Har book ka price alag hai.

  • ðŸ“š Normal stack: "Sabse sasti book kaun si?" â†’ Saari books check karo
  • ðŸ“š Smart stack: Har book ke saath ek chit chipka do jisme likha ho â€” "Ab tak ki sabse sasti book: â‚¹X"
  • ðŸ“š Ab jab bhi poochho "sabse sasti?" â†’ Sirf top book ki chit dekho! O(1)! ðŸŽ‰

ðŸ’¡ Key Insight: Har level pe minimum track karo! Jab naya element aaye, uska minimum = min(current_value, previous_minimum)

ðŸ¤” Naive Approach Kyu Fail Hota Hai?

Naive Approach 
# âŒ Wrong Approach
def getMin(self):
    return min(self.stack)  # O(n) - poora stack scan!

# Interview me ye answer diya â†’ Reject! ðŸ˜…
ðŸ”´ Naive vs Smart Approach
âŒ Naive Approach
1
getMin() called
2
Scan entire stack
O(n) time ðŸ¢
3
Interview Reject! âŒ
âœ… Smart Approach
1
getMin() called
2
Return min_stack.top()
O(1) time âš¡
3
Interview Pass! âœ…

âœ… Approach A: Two Stack Method (Industry Standard)

O(1) all ops O(n)

ðŸ’¡ Core Idea â€” Har Level Ka Minimum Store Karo

ðŸŽ¯ Golden Rule: Do stacks maintain karo â€”

  1. stack â†’ Actual values store karta hai
  2. min_stack â†’ Har level tak ka minimum store karta hai

Dono stacks same size me chalte hain. Jab bhi kuch push/pop ho, dono me karo!

ðŸ“Š Two Stack Architecture
ðŸ“š Main Stack
3 â† top
1 â˜… min
4
2
5
ðŸ“‰ Min Stack
1 â† top
1 â˜… min
2
2
5
ðŸ’¡ Rule: min_stack.top() = Current minimum in entire stack!

âš™ï¸ Operations Ka Logic

ðŸ“¤ PUSH Operation Flow
push(val)
â†’
min_stack empty?
YES: push(val)
NO: push(min(val, top))
â†“
stack.push(val) â†’ Done! O(1)
ðŸ“¥ POP Operation Flow
pop()
â†’
stack.pop()
â†’
min_stack.pop()
â†’
Done! O(1)
ðŸ”„ Dono stacks se pop karo â€” sync me rahenge!
ðŸ” getMin Operation
getMin()
â†’
return min_stack.top()
â†’
âš¡ O(1) - No scanning!

ðŸ“º Visual Dry Run â€” Step by Step

ðŸŽ¬ Operations Sequence
1
push(5)
stack: [5] | min_stack: [5] | min = 5
2
push(2)
stack: [5,2] | min_stack: [5,2] | min = 2 ðŸ†•
3
push(4)
stack: [5,2,4] | min_stack: [5,2,2] | min = 2 (unchanged)
4
push(1) ðŸŽ¯ NEW MIN!
stack: [5,2,4,1] | min_stack: [5,2,2,1] | min = 1 ðŸ†•
ðŸ” Detailed Dry Run
Operation stack min_stack getMin() Explanation
push(5) [5] [5] 5 First element, min = 5
push(2) [5, 2] [5, 2] 2 min(2, 5) = 2
push(4) [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 min(4, 2) = 2 (min unchanged)
push(1) [5, 2, 4, 1] [5, 2, 2, 1] 1 min(1, 2) = 1 (NEW MIN!)
getMin() [5, 2, 4, 1] [5, 2, 2, 1] 1 Return min_stack.top()
pop() [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 Pop from both stacks
top() [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 Return stack.top() = 4
getMin() [5, 2, 4] [5, 2, 2] 2 min_stack.top() = 2
Python - Approach A (Two Stacks) 
class MinStack:
    """
    Min Stack using Two Stacks - Industry Standard Solution
    
    Approach:
    - Maintain two stacks: one for values, one for minimums
    - min_stack[i] = minimum value from index 0 to i
    - Both stacks always have same size
    
    Time: O(1) for all operations
    Space: O(n) for the extra min_stack
    """
    
    def __init__(self):
        self.stack = []      # Actual values
        self.min_stack = []  # Minimum at each level
    
    def push(self, val: int) -> None:
        """
        Push value onto stack and update minimum.
        
        Logic:
        - Always push to main stack
        - For min_stack: push min(val, current_min)
        """
        self.stack.append(val)
        
        if not self.min_stack:
            # First element - it's the minimum
            self.min_stack.append(val)
        else:
            # New min = min(new_value, previous_min)
            current_min = self.min_stack[-1]
            new_min = min(val, current_min)
            self.min_stack.append(new_min)
    
    def pop(self) -> None:
        """
        Pop from both stacks to keep them in sync.
        
        Why pop from both?
        - If we only pop from main stack, min_stack
          would have wrong size and wrong minimum
        """
        self.stack.pop()
        self.min_stack.pop()
    
    def top(self) -> int:
        """
        Return top element of main stack.
        Standard stack operation - O(1)
        """
        return self.stack[-1]
    
    def getMin(self) -> int:
        """
        Return current minimum - THE MAGIC!
        
        Why this works:
        - min_stack[-1] always has minimum of all elements
          currently in the stack
        - No scanning needed! O(1)
        """
        return self.min_stack[-1]


# ============ USAGE EXAMPLE ============
if __name__ == "__main__":
    minStack = MinStack()
    
    print("=== MinStack Demo ===")
    
    minStack.push(5)
    print(f"push(5) â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    minStack.push(2)
    print(f"push(2) â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    minStack.push(4)
    print(f"push(4) â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    minStack.push(1)
    print(f"push(1) â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    
    print(f"\ngetMin() = {minStack.getMin()}")  # 1
    
    minStack.pop()
    print(f"\npop() â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_stack={minStack.min_stack}")
    print(f"getMin() = {minStack.getMin()}")  # 2
    
    print(f"\ntop() = {minStack.top()}")  # 4

âœ… Interview Verdict: Ye approach most preferred hai! Clean, readable, bug-free, production-safe. Interviewer isse hi expect karta hai! ðŸŽ¯

âš ï¸ Approach B: Single Stack Encoding Trick (Advanced)

O(1) all ops O(1) extra

âš ï¸ Warning â€” Ye Approach Risky Hai!

ðŸ”´ Interview me sirf tab bolo jab explicitly pucha jaaye:
"Can you do it with O(1) extra space?" ya "Can you use single stack?"

Otherwise, Approach A stick karo! Ye approach error-prone hai.

ðŸ§  Core Idea â€” Encoding Magic

ðŸ’¡ Mind-bending trick: Hum stack me actual value store nahi karte!

Instead, hum store karte hain:

encoded_value = val - current_min

Aur saath me ek variable min_val maintain karte hain.

ðŸ” Encoding Logic
ðŸ“ Encoding Rules
1
diff = val - min_val
2
diff < 0?
YES â†’ New minimum! Update min_val
NO â†’ Normal push, min unchanged
ðŸ”“ Decoding Rules
1
Negative diff = This WAS the minimum
2
Get value: return min_val
3
Restore: old_min = min_val - diff

ðŸ“œ Rules Explained

ðŸ“¤ PUSH with Encoding
push(val)
â†’
stack empty?
YES: push(0), min_val = val
NO: diff = val - min_val
â†“
diff < 0?
YES: min_val = val ðŸ†•
NO: min unchanged
ðŸ“¥ POP with Decoding
pop()
â†’
diff = stack.pop()
â†’
diff < 0?
YES: min_val = min_val - diff (restore!)
NO: min unchanged
ðŸ‘€ TOP with Decoding
top()
â†’
diff = stack.top()
â†’
diff < 0?
YES: return min_val (this IS min)
NO: return min_val + diff

â“ Why diff < 0 Important Hai?

ðŸŽ¯ Negative diff ka matlab:

  • diff = val - min_val
  • Agar diff < 0 â†’ val < min_val
  • Matlab ye element new minimum tha!

ðŸ‘‰ Isliye negative diff dekhte hi samajh jaate hain: "Ye wala element minimum tha, aur iske pehle ka minimum min_val - diff se recover hoga!"

ðŸ” Dry Run â€” Encoding Trick

Step-by-Step Trace
Operation val diff stack min_val Explanation
push(5) 5 0 [0] 5 First element, push 0
push(2) 2 -3 [0, -3] 2 2-5=-3 < 0 â†’ NEW MIN!
push(4) 4 2 [0, -3, 2] 2 4-2=2 â‰¥ 0 â†’ normal
top() - 2 [0, -3, 2] 2 diffâ‰¥0 â†’ return 2+2=4 âœ“
getMin() - - [0, -3, 2] 2 return min_val = 2
pop() - 2 [0, -3] 2 diffâ‰¥0 â†’ min unchanged
pop() - -3 [0] 5 diff<0 â†’ restore: 2-(-3)=5
getMin() - - [0] 5 return min_val = 5 âœ“
Python - Approach B (Single Stack Encoding) 
class MinStack:
    """
    Min Stack using Encoding Trick - Single Stack, O(1) Extra Space
    
    Approach:
    - Store diff = val - current_min instead of actual value
    - Negative diff indicates: this element is/was the minimum
    - Decode using min_val when accessing
    
    Time: O(1) for all operations
    Space: O(1) extra (only min_val variable)
    
    WARNING: This approach is clever but error-prone!
    Use only when explicitly asked for O(1) space.
    """
    
    def __init__(self):
        self.stack = []    # Stores differences, not actual values!
        self.min_val = 0   # Current minimum
    
    def push(self, val: int) -> None:
        """
        Push encoded value onto stack.
        
        Encoding Logic:
        - First element: push 0, set min_val = val
        - Otherwise: push (val - min_val)
        - If val < min_val: update min_val (negative diff signals this)
        """
        if not self.stack:
            # First element - push 0, this becomes the baseline
            self.stack.append(0)
            self.min_val = val
        else:
            # Calculate difference from current minimum
            diff = val - self.min_val
            self.stack.append(diff)
            
            # If diff is negative, we have a new minimum!
            if diff < 0:
                self.min_val = val
    
    def pop(self) -> None:
        """
        Pop and potentially restore old minimum.
        
        Decoding Logic:
        - If popped diff < 0: this element WAS the minimum
        - Need to restore: old_min = current_min - diff
        """
        diff = self.stack.pop()
        
        # Negative diff means we're removing a minimum element
        # Need to restore the previous minimum
        if diff < 0:
            # old_min = min_val - diff
            # (since diff = old_val - old_min, and old_val == min_val when diff < 0)
            self.min_val = self.min_val - diff
    
    def top(self) -> int:
        """
        Decode and return actual top value.
        
        Decoding Logic:
        - If diff < 0: actual value = min_val (this IS the minimum)
        - If diff >= 0: actual value = min_val + diff
        """
        diff = self.stack[-1]
        
        if diff < 0:
            # This element is the current minimum
            return self.min_val
        else:
            # Decode: actual_value = min_val + diff
            return self.min_val + diff
    
    def getMin(self) -> int:
        """
        Return current minimum.
        Simply return min_val - O(1)!
        """
        return self.min_val


# ============ USAGE EXAMPLE ============
if __name__ == "__main__":
    minStack = MinStack()
    
    print("=== MinStack (Encoding) Demo ===\n")
    
    minStack.push(5)
    print(f"push(5) â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: First element, push 0, min=5")
    
    minStack.push(2)
    print(f"\npush(2) â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=2-5=-3 < 0 â†’ NEW MIN! push -3, update min=2")
    
    minStack.push(4)
    print(f"\npush(4) â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=4-2=2 >= 0 â†’ normal push")
    
    print(f"\ntop() = {minStack.top()}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=2 >= 0 â†’ actual = 2+2 = 4")
    
    print(f"\ngetMin() = {minStack.getMin()}")
    
    minStack.pop()
    print(f"\npop() â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=2 >= 0 â†’ min unchanged")
    
    minStack.pop()
    print(f"\npop() â†’ stack={minStack.stack}, min_val={minStack.min_val}")
    print(f"  Explanation: diff=-3 < 0 â†’ restore min = 2-(-3) = 5")

ðŸ“Š Approach A vs Approach B â€” Interview Comparison

Feature Two Stack (A) Encoding Trick (B)
Time Complexity O(1) all ops O(1) all ops
Space Complexity O(n) extra O(1) extra
Code Simplicity â­â­â­â­â­ â­â­
Bug Risk Low High
Readability Excellent Tricky
Interview Safe âœ… Always âš ï¸ Only if asked
Production Ready âœ… Yes âŒ Risky
Integer Overflow Risk None Possible with large values

ðŸŽ¤ Interview Tips â€” Min Stack

  • ðŸ“š Default answer: Always start with Two Stack approach â€” clean, simple, no bugs!
  • ðŸŽ¯ If asked for O(1) space: Then mention encoding trick, but explain the trade-offs
  • âš ï¸ Encoding limitations: Integer overflow possible with very large/small values
  • ðŸ’¡ Follow-up ready: "Can you implement Max Stack too?" (Same concept, track max instead)
  • ðŸ”¥ Variation: "getMin() that returns element AND its index" â€” need more bookkeeping

âš ï¸ Common Pitfalls â€” Avoid These Mistakes!

âŒ Pitfall 1: Single min variable without tracking history
# WRONG!
class BadMinStack:
    def __init__(self):
        self.stack = []
        self.min_val = float('inf')
    
    def push(self, val):
        self.stack.append(val)
        self.min_val = min(self.min_val, val)
    
    def pop(self):
        val = self.stack.pop()
        # BUG: What if val == min_val?
        # min_val is now wrong! ðŸ˜±

Problem: When you pop the minimum element, you lose track of the next minimum!

âŒ Pitfall 2: Forgetting to sync both stacks
# WRONG!
def pop(self):
    self.stack.pop()
    # Forgot to pop from min_stack!
    # Now sizes are different, getMin() gives wrong answer
âŒ Pitfall 3: Empty stack edge case
# WRONG!
def push(self, val):
    self.stack.append(val)
    # BUG: min_stack[-1] fails if min_stack is empty!
    self.min_stack.append(min(val, self.min_stack[-1]))

Fix: Always check if min_stack is empty first!

ðŸ“Š Complexity Summary

Operation Two Stack Encoding
push() O(1) O(1)
pop() O(1) O(1)
top() O(1) O(1)
getMin() O(1) O(1)
Space O(n) O(1) extra

ðŸ”¥ Interview One-liner

"The safest MinStack uses two stacks where each level stores the current minimum; a single-stack encoding trick exists for O(1) space but is harder to reason about and error-prone â€” use it only when explicitly asked!"

ðŸ”

Binary Search

Sorted arrays mein O(log n) mein search â€” Divide & Conquer ka magic!

2 Problems
ðŸ“š Problem #16

Find Minimum in Rotated Sorted Array

Rotated sorted array mein minimum dhundho â€” Binary Search ka twist! ðŸ”„

ðŸŸ¡ Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek sorted array nums diya hai jo k times rotate kiya gaya hai. Tumhe array ka minimum element find karna hai.

ðŸŽ¯ Rotation ka matlab: Array ke end se elements uthake front mein daal diye
ðŸ“Œ [1,2,3,4,5] â†’ 2 times rotate â†’ [4,5,1,2,3]
ðŸŽ¯ Goal: Minimum element dhundho (yahan 1)

Example 1:

nums = [3,4,5,1,2]

Output: 1

Explanation: Original sorted array [1,2,3,4,5] ko 3 times rotate kiya

Example 2:

nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2]

Output: 0

Example 3:

nums = [11,13,15,17]

Output: 11 â€” No rotation, already sorted!

ðŸŽ­ Real-life Analogy â€” Circular Queue Mein Sabse Chhota Dhundho!

Scenario: Socho tumhare paas ek circular table hai jismein numbered cards rakhe hain (1 se 7 tak, sorted). Kisi ne table ghuma di! ðŸ”„ Ab tumhe sabse chhota number dhundhna hai.

Observation: Rotation ke baad bhi ek interesting pattern hai â€” do sorted parts ban gaye!
â€¢ Part 1: [4, 5, 6, 7] â€” sorted, bade numbers
â€¢ Part 2: [1, 2, 3] â€” sorted, chhote numbers (minimum yahan hai!)

Key Insight: Minimum hamesha us jagah hoga jahan "big se small" ka jump ho! Ye wo point hai jahan rotation hui thi (pivot point)! ðŸ“

ðŸ’¡ Binary Search Magic: Har step pe decide karo ki minimum LEFT mein hai ya RIGHT mein. Agar mid element last element se bada hai â†’ minimum RIGHT side mein hai! Nahi toh LEFT mein (ya mid hi hai)!

ðŸŽ¤ Interview Tips â€” Binary Search Variations Master Karo!

  • ðŸ” Binary Search kab use karein: "Array sorted hai (ya partially sorted), toh O(log n) possible hai. Linear search se better kar sakte hain!"
  • ðŸ“Š Pattern recognize karo: "Rotated array do sorted subarrays mein divide hota hai. Minimum wo point hai jahan drop hota hai!"
  • âš ï¸ Edge cases batao:
    â€¢ No rotation: [1,2,3,4] â†’ first element hi minimum
    â€¢ Single element: [5] â†’ wo hi minimum
    â€¢ Two elements: [2,1] â†’ compare karo
    â€¢ Full rotation (n times): Same as original sorted
  • ðŸ§  Key decision explain karo: "Har step pe compare karta hun mid vs right. Agar mid > right, minimum right mein hai. Agar mid â‰¤ right, minimum left mein ya mid hai!"
  • ðŸ”„ Related problem mention karo: "Search in Rotated Array bhi similar hai â€” pehle minimum find karo, phir correct half mein search karo!"

ðŸ§  Kyun Binary Search Kaam Karta Hai? â€” Deep Dive!

Core Insight: Rotated sorted array mein hamesha ek "inflection point" hota hai jahan big number ke baad chhota number aata hai. Minimum wahi hai!

Decision Logic:
â€¢ Array: [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2] (0 = minimum)
â€¢ Compare mid with right:
  â†’ If nums[mid] > nums[right]: Minimum is in RIGHT half (jump happened)
  â†’ If nums[mid] â‰¤ nums[right]: Minimum is in LEFT half or is mid itself

Example walkthrough: [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2]
â€¢ mid=7, right=2 â†’ 7>2 â†’ minimum RIGHT mein hai âœ…
â€¢ mid=0, right=2 â†’ 0â‰¤2 â†’ minimum LEFT mein ya mid hai â†’ check left
â€¢ Eventually 0 milega!

â“ Common Follow-up Questions â€” Tayyar Raho!

Q1: "Agar duplicates allowed hon toh?" (Find Min II)
â†’ Tricky! Jab nums[mid]==nums[right], right-- karo. Worst case O(n) ban sakta hai!

Q2: "Specific target search karna ho rotated array mein?"
â†’ Pehle minimum find karo (pivot), phir decide karo left half mein search karna hai ya right half mein!

Q3: "Kitni baar rotate hua hai ye kaise pata karein?"
â†’ Minimum ka index = number of rotations! Index 4 pe minimum â†’ 4 times rotated!

Q4: "Agar descending order mein sorted ho toh?"
â†’ Comparisons flip karo! Maximum dhundhna easy hoga, minimum end mein hoga!

ðŸ”„ Rotated Array Ka Structure

Original: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]  (sorted ascending)

Rotated:  [4, 5, 6, 7, 1, 2, 3]  (rotated by 4)
          â”‚â†â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’â”‚ â”‚â†â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’â”‚
          Sorted â†‘   Sorted â†“
          (Higher)   (Lower)  
                     â†‘
                   MINIMUM!

Key Observation:
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  Rotated array has TWO sorted halves!          â”‚
â”‚                                                â”‚
â”‚  Left half:  [4, 5, 6, 7] â†’ sorted, HIGHER     â”‚
â”‚  Right half: [1, 2, 3]    â†’ sorted, LOWER      â”‚
â”‚                                                â”‚
â”‚  Minimum = First element of right half! ðŸŽ¯     â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Binary Search Trick:
- Compare mid with rightmost element
- If nums[mid] > nums[right] â†’ min is in RIGHT half
- If nums[mid] < nums[right] â†’ min is in LEFT half (including mid)
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Simple hai â€” saare elements check karo, sabse chhota return karo! ðŸ”

Rotation ho ya na ho, minimum toh array mein hai hi. Poora scan karo aur minimum track karo.

ðŸ’­ Jaise class mein sabse chhota student dhundhna ho â€” sabko khada karke compare karo!

Python Code

# ============================================
# ðŸ” BRUTE FORCE: Find Minimum in Rotated Array
# ============================================
# Approach: Simple hai â€” poora array scan karo!
# Rotation ho ya na ho, minimum toh hai hi andar ðŸ˜„

def findMin(nums):
    """
    Sabse simple tarika â€” Python ka built-in min() use karo
    Time: O(n) kyunki poora array traverse hota hai
    """
    return min(nums)


# --------------------------------------------
# ðŸ“ Manual Implementation (Interview ke liye)
# --------------------------------------------
def findMin_manual(nums):
    """
    Khud se minimum find karo â€” bina built-in function ke
    Yeh approach interviewer ko dikhao pehle!
    """
    # Step 1: Pehle element ko minimum maan lo
    minimum = nums[0]
    
    # Step 2: Baaki sabko check karo
    for num in nums:
        # Agar current element chhota hai, update karo
        if num < minimum:
            minimum = num
    
    # Step 3: Sabse chhota return karo
    return minimum


# ðŸ§ª Testing
print(findMin([3, 4, 5, 1, 2]))       # Output: 1 âœ…
print(findMin([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2])) # Output: 0 âœ…
print(findMin([11, 13, 15, 17]))      # Output: 11 âœ… (no rotation)
â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)

âš ï¸ Works, but we're not using the fact that array is SORTED! Can we do better? ðŸ¤”

2

Binary Search

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Rotated sorted array ki ek special property hai: ðŸŽ¯

Ek portion sorted hai, doosra mein rotation point (minimum) hai!

  • Agar left half sorted hai â†’ minimum RIGHT mein hoga
  • Agar right half sorted hai â†’ minimum LEFT mein hoga (ya mid pe)
  • Har step mein half array eliminate karo!
ðŸ’­ Sochko â€” agar left side sorted hai (ascending), toh rotation point right mein hai!

Algorithm Steps

1
Initialize: left = 0, right = n-1, res = nums[0]
2
Check sorted: Agar nums[left] < nums[right] â†’ already sorted, return min(res, nums[left])
3
Find mid: mid = (left + right) // 2
4
Update res: res = min(res, nums[mid])
5
Decide: Agar nums[mid] >= nums[left] â†’ left sorted, search RIGHT. Else search LEFT.

Python Code

# ============================================
# ðŸ” BINARY SEARCH: Find Minimum in Rotated Array
# ============================================
# Key Insight: Rotated array = 2 sorted halves!
# Ek half HIGHER values wala, ek LOWER values wala
# Minimum = Lower half ka first element ðŸŽ¯

def findMin(nums):
    """
    Binary Search approach jo sorted property use karta hai
    Har step mein half array eliminate karte hain!
    
    Time: O(log n) â€” kyunki half-half karte hain
    Space: O(1) â€” sirf pointers use kar rahe
    """
    
    # Step 1: Initialize karo pointers aur result
    res = nums[0]              # Pehle element se start karo
    left = 0                   # Left pointer
    right = len(nums) - 1      # Right pointer
    
    # Step 2: Binary search loop
    while left <= right:
        
        # ðŸŽ¯ OPTIMIZATION: Agar current window already sorted hai
        # toh minimum left pe hi hai â€” no need to search further!
        if nums[left] < nums[right]:
            res = min(res, nums[left])
            break   # Early exit! ðŸš€
        
        # Middle element calculate karo
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        # Current mid ko consider karo as potential answer
        res = min(res, nums[mid])
        
        # ðŸ¤” DECIDE: Konsi side jaana hai?
        # Agar nums[mid] >= nums[left] â†’ Left half sorted hai
        # Matlab rotation RIGHT side mein hai!
        if nums[mid] >= nums[left]:
            # Left side sorted (higher values) â†’ search RIGHT
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            # Right side sorted (lower values) â†’ search LEFT
            right = mid - 1
    
    return res


# ðŸ§ª Testing with Detailed Output
print(findMin([3, 4, 5, 1, 2]))       # Output: 1 âœ…
print(findMin([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2])) # Output: 0 âœ…
print(findMin([2, 1]))                # Output: 1 âœ… (simple case)

Dry Run

Input: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2]

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]Checkres
106377â‰¥4 â†’ go RIGHT4â†’7
246511<0? No, 1â‰¥0 â†’ go RIGHT7â†’1
344400<2 sorted â†’ break1â†’0 â­

Final Answer: 0 âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(log n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)
3

Binary Search (Lower Bound) âœ¨ CLEANEST

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Aur bhi clean approach! Sirf rightmost se compare karo! ðŸŽ¯

Key insight:

  • Agar nums[mid] < nums[right] â†’ minimum LEFT mein hai (including mid)
  • Agar nums[mid] > nums[right] â†’ minimum RIGHT mein hai (excluding mid)
ðŸ’¡ Why compare with right?
Right element always in the "lower sorted half" hota hai (rotation ke baad).
Agar mid < right â†’ mid bhi lower half mein hai â†’ minimum left side mein ho sakta hai.
Agar mid > right â†’ mid higher half mein hai â†’ minimum right side mein hai!

Python Code

# ============================================
# âœ¨ LOWER BOUND: Cleanest Binary Search Solution
# ============================================
# Sabse elegant approach! Sirf right se compare karo
# Loop end hone pe left automatically minimum pe hoga ðŸŽ¯

def findMin(nums):
    """
    Lower Bound technique â€” sabse clean implementation!
    
    ðŸ’¡ Key Insight:
    - nums[mid] < nums[right] â†’ mid "lower half" mein hai
      â†’ minimum LEFT mein hai (mid included)
    - nums[mid] > nums[right] â†’ mid "higher half" mein hai  
      â†’ minimum RIGHT mein hai (mid excluded)
    
    Time: O(log n)
    Space: O(1)
    """
    
    # Two pointers initialize karo
    left = 0
    right = len(nums) - 1
    
    # Jab tak pointers converge nahi karte
    while left < right:   # Note: < NOT <=
        
        # ðŸ›¡ï¸ Overflow-safe mid calculation
        # (left + right) // 2 se overflow ho sakta hai large arrays mein
        mid = left + (right - left) // 2
        
        # ðŸ”‘ THE KEY COMPARISON: mid vs right
        if nums[mid] < nums[right]:
            # âœ… Mid LOWER half mein hai (smaller values)
            # Minimum left mein ho sakta hai, mid pe bhi ho sakta hai!
            right = mid     # ðŸ‘ˆ mid include karo!
            
        else:  # nums[mid] > nums[right]
            # âœ… Mid HIGHER half mein hai (larger values)
            # Minimum definitely right mein hai, mid pe nahi
            left = mid + 1  # ðŸ‘ˆ mid exclude karo!
    
    # ðŸŽ¯ Loop khatam hone pe left = right = minimum index
    return nums[left]


# ðŸ§ª Testing All Cases
print(findMin([3, 4, 5, 1, 2]))       # Output: 1 âœ… (rotated)
print(findMin([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2])) # Output: 0 âœ… (rotated)
print(findMin([11, 13, 15, 17]))      # Output: 11 âœ… (not rotated)
print(findMin([2, 1]))                # Output: 1 âœ… (simple)
print(findMin([1]))                   # Output: 1 âœ… (single element)

Detailed Dry Run

Input: nums = [3,4,5,1,2]

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]nums[right]CompareAction
1042525 > 2left = 3
2343121 < 2right = 3
End33---left==rightReturn nums[3]=1 â­

Final Answer: 1 âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(log n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)

âš ï¸ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

âŒ

Left Se Compare Karna

Lower bound approach mein nums[mid] ko nums[left] se compare karna galat results deta hai (especially non-rotated arrays mein).

âœ… Fix: Hamesha nums[right] se compare karo!
âŒ

Boundary Update Galat

Jab nums[mid] < nums[right], minimum mid pe bhi ho sakta hai! Isliye right = mid (not mid-1).

âœ… Remember:
â€¢ mid < right â†’ right = mid
â€¢ mid >= right â†’ left = mid + 1
âŒ

Non-Rotated Case Bhoolna

Array agar rotate nahi hua (ya n times rotate hua), toh minimum first element hai. Algorithm handle karna chahiye.

âœ… Fix: Lower bound approach automatically handles this! Loop ends with left=0 for sorted array.

ðŸ“‹ Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Notes
Brute Force (min) O(n) O(1) Simple but ignores sorted property
Binary Search O(log n) O(1) Compare with left, track min
Lower Bound BEST O(log n) O(1) Compare with right, cleanest! âš¡
ðŸ“Œ Key Pattern: Rotated sorted array = 2 sorted halves! Binary search mein nums[mid] vs nums[right] compare karke decide karo â€” minimum LEFT mein hai ya RIGHT mein! ðŸ”
ðŸ“š Problem #17

Search in Rotated Sorted Array

Rotated array mein target dhundho â€” Binary Search ka asli test! ðŸŽ¯

ðŸŸ¡ Medium Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek sorted array nums hai jo k times rotate kiya gaya hai. Ek target value di gayi hai â€” tumhe uska index return karna hai. Agar target nahi mila toh -1 return karo.

ðŸŽ¯ Constraint: O(log n) time mein karna hai â€” matlab Binary Search zaruri hai!
ðŸ“Œ Array mein distinct values hain (koi duplicate nahi)
ðŸ”„ Rotation Example: [1,2,3,4,5] â†’ [4,5,1,2,3]

Example 1:

nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 0

Output: 4 â€” 0 index 4 pe hai!

Example 2:

nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 3

Output: -1 â€” 3 array mein nahi hai!

Example 3:

nums = [1], target = 0

Output: -1 â€” Single element, target different!

ðŸ”„ Rotated Array Ka Structure Samjho

Original Sorted: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7]

Rotated (by 4):  [4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2]
                  â”‚â†â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’â”‚ â”‚â†â”€â”€â”€â”€â†’â”‚
                  HIGHER â†‘   LOWER â†“
                  (Left Half)  (Right Half)
                              â†‘
                           PIVOT (minimum)

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  ðŸŽ¯ KEY INSIGHT:                                     â”‚
â”‚                                                      â”‚
â”‚  Rotated array mein HAMESHA ek half SORTED hoti hai! â”‚
â”‚                                                      â”‚
â”‚  Binary Search mein mid nikalte waqt:                â”‚
â”‚  - Check karo LEFT half sorted hai ya RIGHT half     â”‚
â”‚  - Sorted half mein target ho sakta hai kya?         â”‚
â”‚  - Accordingly left/right pointer move karo!         â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Example: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 0

Step 1: mid = 3 (value = 7)
        Left half [4,5,6,7] sorted hai (4 â‰¤ 7)
        Target 0, is range mein nahi (0 < 4)
        â†’ Search RIGHT half!

Step 2: mid = 5 (value = 1)  
        Left half [0,1] sorted hai (0 â‰¤ 1)
        Target 0, is range mein hai (0 â‰¤ 0 â‰¤ 1)
        â†’ Search LEFT half!

Step 3: mid = 4 (value = 0) â†’ FOUND! Return 4 âœ…
1

Brute Force Approach

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Sabse simple â€” ek-ek element check karo! ðŸ”

Array sorted ho ya rotated ho ya kuch bhi ho â€” linear scan se target mil hi jaayega (agar hai toh). Lekin yeh O(n) hai, problem O(log n) maang raha hai!

ðŸ’­ Jaise phone book mein naam dhundhna â€” ek-ek page dekhte jao! (Sorted hai toh faster ho sakta hai but brute force mein hum ignore karte hain)

Python Code

# ============================================
# ðŸ” BRUTE FORCE: Linear Search in Rotated Array
# ============================================
# Sabse simple approach â€” ek-ek element check karo!
# Rotation ki chinta nahi, bas poora array traverse karo
# âš ï¸ O(n) hai â€” interview mein accept nahi hoga!

def search(nums, target):
    """
    Brute Force Linear Search
    
    ðŸŽ¯ Logic: Har element ko target se compare karo
    - Match mila â†’ index return karo
    - Nahi mila â†’ -1 return karo
    
    Time: O(n) â€” Poora array traverse
    Space: O(1) â€” Koi extra space nahi
    """
    
    # ðŸ”„ Har element check karo
    for i in range(len(nums)):
        if nums[i] == target:
            # âœ… Mil gaya! Index return karo
            return i
    
    # âŒ Poora array check kiya, nahi mila
    return -1


# ðŸ§ª Testing
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 0))   # Output: 4 âœ…
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 3))   # Output: -1 âŒ
print(search([1], 0))                      # Output: -1 âŒ
print(search([1, 3], 3))                   # Output: 1 âœ…
â±ï¸ Time: O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)

âš ï¸ Problem mein O(log n) maanga hai â€” yeh accept nahi hoga interview mein!

2

Binary Search (Two Pass â€” Pivot Pehle Dhundho)

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Rotated array = Do sorted arrays jode hue! ðŸ”—

Two Pass Strategy:

  • Pass 1: Pivot dhundho (minimum element ka index) â€” yeh rotation point hai
  • Pass 2: Decide karo target LEFT half mein hai ya RIGHT half mein
  • Phir us half mein normal binary search karo!
ðŸ’­ Jaise broken ruler â€” pehle dhundho kahan se tuti hai, phir measure karo!

Algorithm Steps

1
Find Pivot: Binary search se minimum element dhundho (rotation point)
2
Decide Half: Target ka value check karo â€” [pivot, end] mein hai ya [0, pivot-1] mein
3
Binary Search: Selected half mein normal binary search chala do

Python Code

# ============================================
# ðŸ” TWO PASS: Pivot Dhundho + Binary Search
# ============================================
# Pass 1: Pehle minimum element (pivot) dhundho
# Pass 2: Phir correct half mein binary search karo
# 
# ðŸ’¡ Rotated array = 2 sorted halves joined together!

def search(nums, target):
    """
    Two Pass Binary Search
    
    ðŸŽ¯ Strategy:
    1. Find pivot (index of minimum element)
    2. Decide which half to search
    3. Run standard binary search on that half
    
    Time: O(log n) â€” 2 binary searches
    Space: O(1)
    """
    n = len(nums)
    
    # ========================================
    # ðŸ“ PASS 1: Find Pivot (Minimum Element)
    # ========================================
    # Pivot = jahan se rotation shuru hui
    # Iske left mein bade elements, right mein chhote
    
    left, right = 0, n - 1
    
    while left < right:
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        # Agar mid > right â†’ minimum RIGHT mein hai
        if nums[mid] > nums[right]:
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            # Minimum LEFT mein hai (including mid)
            right = mid
    
    # ðŸŽ¯ Ab left = right = pivot index
    pivot = left
    
    # ========================================
    # ðŸ“ PASS 2: Decide Which Half to Search
    # ========================================
    # Reset pointers
    left, right = 0, n - 1
    
    # Target kis half mein hai?
    # Right half: [pivot, n-1] mein smallest se largest tak
    if target >= nums[pivot] and target <= nums[right]:
        # âœ… Target RIGHT half mein hai
        left = pivot
    else:
        # âœ… Target LEFT half mein hai
        right = pivot - 1
    
    # ========================================
    # ðŸ“ Standard Binary Search
    # ========================================
    while left <= right:
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        if nums[mid] == target:
            # ðŸŽ‰ Mil gaya!
            return mid
        elif nums[mid] < target:
            left = mid + 1
        else:
            right = mid - 1
    
    # âŒ Nahi mila
    return -1


# ðŸ§ª Testing
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 0))   # Output: 4 âœ…
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 3))   # Output: -1 âŒ
print(search([1], 0))                      # Output: -1 âŒ
print(search([1, 3], 1))                   # Output: 0 âœ…

Dry Run

Input: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 0

Pass 1: Find Pivot

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]nums[right]Action
1063727 > 2 â†’ left = 4
2465121 < 2 â†’ right = 5
3454010 < 1 â†’ right = 4

Pivot = 4 (nums[4] = 0 minimum hai)

Pass 2: Binary Search â€” target 0 â‰¥ nums[4] aur â‰¤ nums[6] â†’ RIGHT half search

Search [4,6], mid = 5 â†’ nums[5]=1 > 0 â†’ right = 4

Search [4,4], mid = 4 â†’ nums[4]=0 = target â†’ Return 4 âœ…

â±ï¸ Time: O(log n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)
3

Binary Search (One Pass) âœ¨ OPTIMAL

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Ek hi pass mein kaam khatam! ðŸš€ Pivot alag se dhundhne ki zarurat nahi!

Key Observation: Rotated array mein mid ke around HAMESHA ek half sorted hoti hai!

  • Left half sorted: nums[left] â‰¤ nums[mid]
  • Right half sorted: Otherwise

Sorted half mein easily check kar sakte hain ki target wahan hai ya nahi!

ðŸ’¡ Logic:
1. Check karo LEFT sorted hai ya RIGHT sorted
2. Sorted half mein dekho â€” target us range mein hai kya?
3. Agar hai â†’ us taraf jao, nahi hai â†’ doosri taraf jao!

Algorithm Steps

1
Calculate mid: mid = (left + right) // 2
2
Check target: Agar nums[mid] == target â†’ Return mid
3
If LEFT sorted (nums[left] â‰¤ nums[mid]):
- Target in range [left, mid]? â†’ Search left
- Else â†’ Search right
4
If RIGHT sorted:
- Target in range [mid, right]? â†’ Search right
- Else â†’ Search left

Python Code

# ============================================
# âœ¨ ONE PASS: Single Binary Search (OPTIMAL)
# ============================================
# Ek hi pass mein sab kuch â€” no need to find pivot first!
# 
# ðŸ’¡ Key Insight: 
# Rotated array mein mid ke around HAMESHA ek half sorted hoti hai!
# Us sorted half mein check karo â€” target wahan hai kya?

def search(nums, target):
    """
    One Pass Binary Search â€” OPTIMAL Solution!
    
    ðŸŽ¯ Logic har iteration mein:
    1. Check karo LEFT half sorted hai ya RIGHT half
    2. Sorted half mein dekho â€” target us range mein fit hota hai?
    3. Accordingly pointer move karo!
    
    Time: O(log n) â€” Single binary search
    Space: O(1) â€” No extra space
    """
    
    left, right = 0, len(nums) - 1
    
    while left <= right:
        mid = (left + right) // 2
        
        # ðŸŽ‰ Target mil gaya!
        if nums[mid] == target:
            return mid
        
        # ========================================
        # ðŸ“ Check: LEFT half sorted hai kya?
        # ========================================
        # nums[left] <= nums[mid] matlab left to mid sorted hai
        if nums[left] <= nums[mid]:
            # âœ… LEFT HALF is SORTED!
            
            # Ab check karo â€” target is sorted range mein hai?
            # Range: [nums[left], nums[mid]]
            if target > nums[mid] or target < nums[left]:
                # âŒ Target LEFT sorted half mein NAHI hai
                # â†’ RIGHT half mein search karo
                left = mid + 1
            else:
                # âœ… Target LEFT sorted half mein hai
                # â†’ LEFT mein search karo
                right = mid - 1
        
        # ========================================
        # ðŸ“ RIGHT half sorted hai
        # ========================================
        else:
            # âœ… RIGHT HALF is SORTED!
            # Range: [nums[mid], nums[right]]
            
            if target < nums[mid] or target > nums[right]:
                # âŒ Target RIGHT sorted half mein NAHI hai
                # â†’ LEFT half mein search karo
                right = mid - 1
            else:
                # âœ… Target RIGHT sorted half mein hai
                # â†’ RIGHT mein search karo
                left = mid + 1
    
    # âŒ Poora search kiya, nahi mila
    return -1


# ðŸ§ª Testing All Cases
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 0))   # Output: 4 âœ…
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 3))   # Output: -1 âŒ
print(search([4, 5, 6, 7, 0, 1, 2], 5))   # Output: 1 âœ…
print(search([1], 0))                      # Output: -1 âŒ
print(search([1, 3], 3))                   # Output: 1 âœ…
print(search([3, 1], 1))                   # Output: 1 âœ… (rotated)
print(search([1, 2, 3, 4, 5], 3))         # Output: 2 âœ… (not rotated)

Detailed Dry Run

Input: nums = [4,5,6,7,0,1,2], target = 5

Iterleftrightmidnums[mid]Sorted HalfTarget in range?Action
10637LEFT [4,5,6,7]5 in [4,7]? âœ…right = 2
20215-FOUND!Return 1 â­

Final Answer: 1 âœ…

Kyun nums[left] <= nums[mid] mein <=?

ðŸ¤” Common Question: < ki jagah <= kyun use kiya?

Answer: Edge case jab left == mid ho!
  • Jab array small ho (2 elements), mid aur left same ho sakte hain
  • Us case mein nums[left] == nums[mid] hoga
  • < use kiya toh galat half select ho jayega!
  • <= se single element bhi "sorted" maana jaata hai âœ…
â±ï¸ Time: O(log n)
ðŸ’¾ Space: O(1)

âš ï¸ Common Galtiyan (Pitfalls)

âŒ

Strict Inequality (<) Use Karna

One-pass approach mein nums[left] < nums[mid] use karna galat hai jab left == mid. Small arrays mein fail hoga!

âœ… Fix: nums[left] <= nums[mid] use karo â€” equal case handle hoga!
âŒ

Pivot Finding aur Target Finding Mix Karna

Two-pass approach mein pivot dhundhne ka logic alag hai, target search ka alag. Dono ko mix mat karo!

âœ… Fix: Clear separation rakho â€” pehle pivot, phir search. Ya one-pass use karo!
âŒ

Non-Rotated Array Handle Na Karna

Array agar rotate nahi hua ([1,2,3,4,5]), tab bhi code work karna chahiye. Pivot index 0 hoga.

âœ… Test: Non-rotated arrays pe bhi test karo!
âŒ

Target Range Check Galat

Sorted half mein target check karte waqt >= aur <= carefully use karo, nahi toh boundary elements miss ho jayenge!

âœ… Fix: target >= nums[left] AND target <= nums[mid] â€” dono bounds check karo!

ðŸ“‹ Quick Comparison Table

Approach Time Space Hinglish Summary
Brute Force O(n) O(1) Ek-ek element check karo ðŸ˜…
Two Pass (Pivot First) O(log n) O(1) Pehle minimum dhundho, phir search
One Pass BEST O(log n) O(1) Sorted half identify karo, phir decide! âš¡
ðŸ“Œ Key Pattern: Rotated array mein HAMESHA ek half sorted hoti hai! Binary search mein sorted half identify karo â†’ check karo target us range mein hai? â†’ accordingly move karo! ðŸŽ¯
ðŸ”—

Linked List

Pointers aur nodes ka game â€” interview ka favourite topic!

7 problems
ðŸ”— Problem #18

Reverse Linked List

Linked List ko ulta karo â€” DSA ka Classic Problem! ðŸ”„

ðŸŸ¢ Easy Level

Problem Kya Hai?

Ek singly linked list ka head diya gaya hai. Tumhe list ko reverse karke new head return karna hai.

ðŸŽ¯ Simple Words Mein: List ulti kar do!
ðŸ“Œ 1 â†’ 2 â†’ 3 â†’ 4 â†’ 5 ban jaayega 5 â†’ 4 â†’ 3 â†’ 2 â†’ 1
ðŸ”„ Har node ka next pointer peeche wale node ki taraf point karega!

Example 1:

head = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Output: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1]

Example 2:

head = [1, 2]

Output: [2, 1]

Example 3:

head = []

Output: [] â€” Empty list remains empty!

ðŸŽ“ Prerequisites: Linked List Kya Hai? (Basics Samjho Pehle!)

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                    SINGLY LINKED LIST                            â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚                                                                  â”‚
â”‚   Array vs Linked List:                                          â”‚
â”‚   â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•                                        â”‚
â”‚                                                                  â”‚
â”‚   Array:  [10][20][30][40][50]  â† Continuous memory blocks       â”‚
