# âœ¨ APPROACH 2: RECURSION
# ============================================
# Recursion se end tak jao, unwinding mein pair karo!

class Solution:
    def reorderList(self, head) -> None:
        def rec(root, cur):
            # ðŸ”´ Base case: End tak pahunch gaye
            if not cur:
                return root
            
            # ðŸ”„ Recursively end tak jao
            root = rec(root, cur.next)
            if not root:  # Already done
                return None
            
            tmp = None
            # ðŸŽ¯ Check: Meet ho gaye?
            if root == cur or root.next == cur:
                cur.next = None  # Terminate!
            else:
                # ðŸ”— Pair karo: root â†’ cur â†’ tmp
                tmp = root.next
                root.next = cur
                cur.next = tmp
            
            return tmp  # Next front pointer
        
        head = rec(head, head.next)

Time & Space Complexity

â±ï¸ Time Complexity
O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space Complexity
O(n)
âš ï¸ Recursion Stack: O(n) space use hota hai call stack mein! Still not optimal! ðŸ˜•
3

ðŸ† OPTIMAL â€” Reverse & Merge (O(1) Space!)

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Brilliant Idea: 3-Step Process! ðŸŽ¯

  1. Find Middle: Slow/Fast pointers se list ko 2 halves mein divide karo!
  2. Reverse Second Half: Second half ko reverse kar do!
  3. Merge: Dono halves ko alternately merge karo!
ðŸ”¥ Why It Works: Reverse karne se last elements pehle aa jayenge, phir simply merge kar do!

ðŸŽ¨ Step-by-Step Visualization

Step 1ï¸âƒ£: Find Middle (Slow/Fast Pointers)

INPUT:    1 â”€â”€â”€â–º 2 â”€â”€â”€â–º 3 â”€â”€â”€â–º 4 â”€â”€â”€â–º 5 â”€â”€â”€â–º NULL
          â†‘             â†‘                    â†‘
        slow          slow                 fast
       (start)       (ends)               (ends)

ðŸ¢ Slow: Moves 1 step at a time
ðŸ‡ Fast: Moves 2 steps at a time

After loop: slow = node(3) â†’ This is the MIDDLE!

ðŸ¢ slow stops at 3 (middle) | ðŸ‡ fast reaches end

Step 2ï¸âƒ£: Reverse Second Half

Split at middle:
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

FIRST HALF:      1 â”€â”€â”€â–º 2 â”€â”€â”€â–º 3 â”€â”€â”€â–º NULL
                 ðŸŸ¢      ðŸŸ¢      ðŸŸ¢

SECOND HALF:     4 â”€â”€â”€â–º 5 â”€â”€â”€â–º NULL
                 ðŸŸ       ðŸŸ 

After REVERSING second half:
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

FIRST HALF:      1 â”€â”€â”€â–º 2 â”€â”€â”€â–º 3
                 ðŸŸ¢      ðŸŸ¢      ðŸŸ¢

SECOND HALF:     5 â”€â”€â”€â–º 4 â”€â”€â”€â–º NULL  (REVERSED!)
                 ðŸŸ       ðŸŸ 

First Half: 1â†’2â†’3 | Second Half (Reversed): 5â†’4

Step 3ï¸âƒ£: Merge Alternately

MERGE: Take one from each list alternately!
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

First:   1 â”€â”€â”€â–º 2 â”€â”€â”€â–º 3          Second:  5 â”€â”€â”€â–º 4
         â†“                                  â†“
         â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”    â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                        â–¼    â–¼
RESULT:  1 â”€â”€â”€â–º 5 â”€â”€â”€â–º 2 â”€â”€â”€â–º 4 â”€â”€â”€â–º 3 â”€â”€â”€â–º NULL
         ðŸŸ¢      ðŸŸ       ðŸŸ¢      ðŸŸ       ðŸŸ¢

Pattern: GREEN â†’ ORANGE â†’ GREEN â†’ ORANGE â†’ GREEN
         (front)  (back)  (front)  (back)  (middle)

Algorithm

  1. Find Middle: Slow/Fast pointer technique use karo
    • slow = head, fast = head.next
    • Loop: while fast and fast.next: slow +1, fast +2
    • Result: slow middle ke pehle wale node pe hoga!
  2. Reverse Second Half:
    • second = slow.next â€” Second half start
    • slow.next = None â€” Disconnect halves!
    • Standard reversal: prev, cur = None, second
  3. Merge Two Lists:
    • first = head, second = reversed_head
    • Loop: while second:
    • Save temps: tmp1 = first.next, tmp2 = second.next
    • Link: first.next = second, second.next = tmp1
    • Move: first = tmp1, second = tmp2
Python ðŸ† OPTIMAL â€” O(1) Space! 
# ============================================
# ðŸ† APPROACH 3: OPTIMAL (Reverse & Merge)
# ============================================
# 3 Steps: Find Middle â†’ Reverse 2nd Half â†’ Merge!
# Time: O(n) | Space: O(1) ðŸ”¥

class Solution:
    def reorderList(self, head) -> None:
        # ðŸ¢ðŸ‡ Step 1: Find middle using slow/fast pointers
        slow, fast = head, head.next
        while fast and fast.next:
            slow = slow.next
            fast = fast.next.next
        
        # ðŸ”„ Step 2: Reverse second half
        second = slow.next
        prev = slow.next = None  # Disconnect!
        
        while second:
            tmp = second.next
            second.next = prev
            prev = second
            second = tmp
        
        # ðŸ”— Step 3: Merge two halves alternately
        first, second = head, prev
        while second:
            tmp1, tmp2 = first.next, second.next
            first.next = second
            second.next = tmp1
            first, second = tmp1, tmp2

ðŸ“‹ Detailed Dry Run â€” Optimal Approach

Input: head = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

Phase 1: Find Middle

IterationslowfastComment
Init12â€”
124slow +1, fast +2
23NULLfast.next NULL! STOP!

âœ… Middle found! slow = 3

Phase 2: Reverse Second Half

Second half: 4 â†’ 5 â†’ NULL

After reversal: 5 â†’ 4 â†’ NULL âœ…

Phase 3: Merge

StepfirstsecondActionResult
1151.next = 5, 5.next = 21â†’5â†’2
2242.next = 4, 4.next = 32â†’4â†’3
33NULLsecond NULL, DONE!3â†’NULL

Final List: 1 â†’ 5 â†’ 2 â†’ 4 â†’ 3 â†’ NULL ðŸŽ‰

Time & Space Complexity

â±ï¸ Time Complexity
O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space Complexity
O(1)
ðŸ† OPTIMAL! Linear time + Constant space! No extra memory! Perfect solution! ðŸš€

âš ï¸ Common Pitfalls â€” Galtiyan Mat Karo!

  1. Incorrect Middle Finding:
    âŒ slow = fast = head â€” Galat initialization!
    âœ… slow = head, fast = head.next â€” Sahi way! Slow exactly pehle half ke last node pe rukta hai!
  2. Forgetting to Disconnect Halves:
    âŒ slow.next ko NULL nahi kiya â†’ Cycle ban jayega!
    âœ… slow.next = None zaroor karo before reversal!
  3. Losing References During Merge:
    âŒ first.next = second karne se original first.next lost!
    âœ… Pehle save karo: tmp1 = first.next, phir link karo!

ðŸ“Š Approach Comparison

Approach Time Space Key Idea
1. Brute Force (Array) O(n) O(n) Store all nodes in array, use two pointers
2. Recursion O(n) O(n) Call stack stores back nodes, pair during unwind
3. Reverse & Merge â­ O(n) O(1) Find middle â†’ Reverse second half â†’ Merge!
ðŸŽ¯ Interview Mein: Approach 3 (Reverse & Merge) hi bolna! Most optimal aur clean! ðŸ’¯
22

Remove Nth Node From End of List

End se Nth node hatao â€” Two Pointers ka Classic Problem! ðŸŽ¯

Medium Linked List Two Pointers

ðŸ“‹ Problem Statement

Ek singly linked list ka head diya gaya hai. Tumhe list ke end se nth node ko remove karna hai aur modified list ka head return karna hai.

Example 1:
Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5], n = 2
Output: [1,2,3,5]
Explanation: End se 2nd node (4) ko remove kiya!
Example 2:
Input: head = [1], n = 1
Output: []
Explanation: Single node hai aur wahi remove karna hai!
Example 3:
Input: head = [1,2], n = 1
Output: [1]
Explanation: End se 1st node (2) ko remove kiya!

ðŸŽ“ Prerequisites â€” Pehle Ye Samjho!

  • Linked List Fundamentals: Singly linked list kaise kaam karta hai â€” node structure, traversal, pointers
  • Two Pointers Technique: Do pointers use karke different positions track karna simultaneously
  • Dummy Node Pattern: Sentinel node jo edge cases (like head removal) ko simple banata hai!
ðŸŽ¯ PROBLEM VISUALIZATION â€” End Se Nth Node
INPUT: n = 2
1
â†’
2
â†’
3
â†’
4 ðŸŽ¯
â†’
5
â†’
NULL
5th 4th 3rd 2nd âœ‚ï¸ 1st
OUTPUT:
1
â†’
2
â†’
3
â†’
5
â†’
NULL
1

Brute Force â€” Array Mein Store Karo!

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Simple Idea: Saare nodes ko array mein daal do! ðŸ“¦

Array mein direct index access hota hai, toh end se nth position easily calculate kar sakte ho!

ðŸ’¡ Kahani Samjho: Linked List mein end tak jaane ke liye traverse karna padta hai (O(n)). Lekin array mein? Direct arr[index] se access! Toh nodes array mein daal do, phir easily delete karo!

Algorithm

  1. Linked list traverse karo aur har node ko array mein push karo
  2. Delete karne wale node ka index calculate karo: removeIndex = len(nodes) - n
  3. Agar removeIndex == 0 â†’ Head ko hi remove karna hai â†’ Return head.next
  4. Otherwise: nodes[removeIndex - 1].next = nodes[removeIndex].next
  5. Modified head return karo!
ðŸ”„ BRUTE FORCE APPROACH FLOW
1
Array Mein Store
1 â†’ 2 â†’ 3 â†’ 4 â†’ 5
nodes = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
2
Index Calculate
removeIndex = len(5) - n(2) = 3
nodes[3] = Node(4) ðŸŽ¯
3
Link Update
nodes[2] (Node 3)
.next =
nodes[3] (4) âœ‚ï¸
â†’
Node 5
4
Result
1 â†’ 2 â†’ 3 â†’ 5 â†’ NULL âœ…
Python Approach 1: Brute Force (Array) 
# ============================================
# âœ¨ APPROACH 1: BRUTE FORCE â€” Array Mein Store!
# ============================================
# Time: O(n) | Space: O(n)

class Solution:
    def removeNthFromEnd(self, head, n):
        # ðŸ“¦ Step 1: Saare nodes array mein daal do
        nodes = []
        cur = head
        while cur:
            nodes.append(cur)
            cur = cur.next
        
        # ðŸ§® Step 2: Remove karne wala index calculate karo
        removeIndex = len(nodes) - n
        
        # ðŸŽ¯ Step 3: Edge case â€” Head remove karna hai?
        if removeIndex == 0:
            return head.next  # Naya head!
        
        # âœ‚ï¸ Step 4: Previous node ko next se connect karo
        nodes[removeIndex - 1].next = nodes[removeIndex].next
        
        return head

Time & Space Complexity

â±ï¸ Time Complexity
O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space Complexity
O(n)
âš ï¸ Drawback: Extra O(n) space use ho raha hai! Can we do better? ðŸ¤”
2

Two Pass Iteration â€” Pehle Count, Phir Delete!

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Idea: Pehle count karo kitne nodes hain, phir delete karo! ðŸ”¢

â€¢ Pass 1: Total nodes count karo (N)
â€¢ End se n-th node matlab start se (N - n)th node!
â€¢ Pass 2: Us position tak jao aur delete karo!

ðŸ’¡ Simple Math: Agar total 5 nodes hain aur end se 2nd chahiye, toh start se 5 - 2 = 3rd node! (0-indexed: index 3)
ðŸ”„ TWO PASS APPROACH VISUALIZATION
P1
PASS 1: Count Nodes
1
N=1
â†’
2
N=2
â†’
3
N=3
â†’
4
N=4
â†’
5
N=5
â†’
NULL
ðŸ§®
CALCULATION
Total N = 5, n = 2 â†’ removeIndex = 5 - 2 = 3
P2
PASS 2: Navigate to Index 2
1
i=0
â†’
2
i=1
â†’
3
i=2 âœ‹
Ã—
4 âœ‚ï¸
â†’
5
3.next = 5 (skip 4!)

Algorithm

  1. Pass 1: List traverse karke total nodes (N) count karo
  2. Calculate: removeIndex = N - n
  3. Agar removeIndex == 0 â†’ Head remove! Return head.next
  4. Pass 2: removeIndex - 1 position tak jao
  5. Us node ka .next update karo: cur.next = cur.next.next
Python Approach 2: Two Pass Iteration 
# ============================================
# âœ¨ APPROACH 2: TWO PASS ITERATION
# ============================================
# Time: O(n) | Space: O(1) âœ…

class Solution:
    def removeNthFromEnd(self, head, n):
        # ðŸ”¢ Pass 1: Total nodes count karo
        N = 0
        cur = head
        while cur:
            N += 1
            cur = cur.next
        
        # ðŸ§® Calculate: Start se kaunsa index delete karna hai?
        removeIndex = N - n
        
        # ðŸŽ¯ Edge case: Head remove karna hai?
        if removeIndex == 0:
            return head.next
        
        # ðŸš¶ Pass 2: removeIndex - 1 tak jao
        cur = head
        for i in range(N - 1):
            if (i + 1) == removeIndex:
                # âœ‚ï¸ Skip the target node!
                cur.next = cur.next.next
                break
            cur = cur.next
        
        return head

Time & Space Complexity

â±ï¸ Time Complexity
O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space Complexity
O(1)
âœ… Better! Space O(1) ho gaya! But 2 passes lagti hain... Can we do in ONE pass? ðŸ¤”
3

Recursion â€” End Se Count Karo Wapis Aate Waqt!

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Brilliant Observation: Recursion naturally end se start ki taraf process karta hai! ðŸ”„

â€¢ Recursion se list ke end tak jao
â€¢ Unwinding phase mein (wapis aate waqt) counter decrement karo
â€¢ Jab counter = 0 â†’ Ye wahi node hai jo delete karni hai â†’ Skip it!

ðŸ’¡ Kahani: Imagine karo tum queue mein ho. Pehle last person tak jao, phir wapis aate waqt count karo: "Ye 1st from end, ye 2nd from end..." Jab n-th mile â†’ Remove!
ðŸ”„ RECURSION CALL STACK â€” n = 2
âž¡ï¸ GOING DOWN (Recursive Calls)
rec(1) â†’ rec(2)
â†“
rec(2) â†’ rec(3)
â†“
rec(3) â†’ rec(4)
â†“
rec(4) â†’ rec(5)
â†“
rec(5) â†’ rec(NULL)
â†“
BASE: return None
â¬…ï¸ UNWINDING (Return Phase)
n[0]=2 â†’ n[0]=1
return 5
â†‘
n[0]=1 â†’ n[0]=0
ðŸŽ¯ n=0! Return 4.next (5)
â†‘
return 3
3.next = 5 âœ…
â†‘
return 2
â†‘
return 1

Algorithm

  1. Base Case: Agar head == None â†’ Return None
  2. Recursive Call: head.next = rec(head.next, n)
  3. Unwinding mein: n[0] -= 1 (counter decrement)
  4. Agar n[0] == 0 â†’ Ye node delete karni hai â†’ Return head.next
  5. Otherwise return head (list rebuild karte jao)
Python Approach 3: Recursion 
# ============================================
# âœ¨ APPROACH 3: RECURSION
# ============================================
# Time: O(n) | Space: O(n) â€” Call Stack!

class Solution:
    def rec(self, head, n):
        # ðŸ”´ Base case: End tak pahunch gaye
        if not head:
            return None
        
        # ðŸ”„ Recursively aage jao
        head.next = self.rec(head.next, n)
        
        # â¬…ï¸ Unwinding: Counter decrement karo
        n[0] -= 1
        
        # ðŸŽ¯ Check: Kya ye wahi node hai jo delete karni hai?
        if n[0] == 0:
            return head.next  # Skip this node!
        
        return head  # Keep this node
    
    def removeNthFromEnd(self, head, n):
        # Note: n ko list mein wrap kiya taaki reference pass ho
        return self.rec(head, [n])
âš ï¸ Python Gotcha: n ko [n] list mein wrap kiya kyunki Python mein integers immutable hain. List pass karne se recursive calls mein same reference share hoti hai!

Time & Space Complexity

â±ï¸ Time Complexity
O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space Complexity
O(n)
âš ï¸ Recursion Stack! O(n) space use hota hai call stack mein. Not optimal for large lists!
4

ðŸ† OPTIMAL â€” Two Pointers with Dummy Node!

Intuition (Sochne Ka Tarika)

Genius Idea: Do pointers use karo jinka gap exactly n ho! ðŸŽ¯

â€¢ Right pointer ko n steps aage bhejo
â€¢ Ab dono pointers ko saath-saath move karo
â€¢ Jab right = NULL â†’ Left exactly us node ke peeche hai jo delete karni hai!

ðŸ’¡ Kahani: Do friends race track pe hain. Pehle wala (right) n steps aage chala gaya. Ab dono saath-saath chalte hain. Jab pehla wala finish line (NULL) pe pahunche â†’ doosra wala exactly n steps peeche hai! ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ðŸƒ
ðŸŽ¯ TWO POINTERS MAGIC â€” Gap = n = 2
0
INITIAL SETUP
DUMMY
â†’
1
â†’
2
â†’
3
â†’
4
â†’
5
â†’
NULL
â¬…ï¸ LEFT     âž¡ï¸ RIGHT
1
Move RIGHT by n=2
DUMMY
â¬…ï¸L
â†’
1
â†’
2
âž¡ï¸R
â†’
3
â†’
4
â†’
5
â†’
NULL
2
Move BOTH until RIGHT = NULL
DUMMY
â†’
1
â†’
2
â†’
3
â¬…ï¸L
â†’
4 âœ‚ï¸
â†’
5
âž¡ï¸R
â†’
NULL
âœ…
FINAL: L.next = L.next.next
1
â†’
2
â†’
3
â†’
5
â†’
NULL

Why Dummy Node?

ðŸ¤” Problem: Agar head hi delete karna hai toh? Left pointer head ke peeche hona chahiye!

âœ… Solution: Dummy node head ke pehle lagao! Left dummy pe start hoga, toh head bhi delete ho sakta hai!
DUMMY NODE SAVES HEAD REMOVAL!
âŒ Without Dummy â€” HEAD DELETE PROBLEM!
1 â¬…ï¸L?
ðŸ¤· Kahan se delete?
â†’
2
âœ… With Dummy â€” CLEAN!
DUMMY
â¬…ï¸L
â†’
1 âœ‚ï¸
â†’
2
L.next = L.next.next â†’ DUMMY points to 2!

Algorithm

  1. Create dummy node pointing to head: dummy.next = head
  2. Initialize: left = dummy, right = head
  3. Move right n steps: while n > 0: right = right.next; n -= 1
  4. Move both until right = NULL: while right: left = left.next; right = right.next
  5. Delete: left.next = left.next.next
  6. Return dummy.next (naya head!)
Python ðŸ† Approach 4: Two Pointers (OPTIMAL!) 
# ============================================
# ðŸ† APPROACH 4: TWO POINTERS â€” OPTIMAL!
# ============================================
# Time: O(n) | Space: O(1) â€” ONE PASS! ðŸš€

class Solution:
    def removeNthFromEnd(self, head, n):
        # ðŸŽ­ Step 1: Dummy node create karo
        dummy = ListNode(0, head)  # dummy.next = head
        left = dummy
        right = head
        
        # âž¡ï¸ Step 2: Right ko n steps aage bhejo
        while n > 0:
            right = right.next
            n -= 1
        
        # ðŸš¶ðŸš¶ Step 3: Dono ko saath-saath move karo
        while right:
            left = left.next
            right = right.next
        
        # âœ‚ï¸ Step 4: Delete the target node!
        left.next = left.next.next
        
        # ðŸŽ‰ Return new head (dummy.next)
        return dummy.next

ðŸ“‹ Detailed Dry Run â€” Two Pointers

Input: head = [1,2,3,4,5], n = 2

Phase 1: Initial Setup

dummy â†’ 1 â†’ 2 â†’ 3 â†’ 4 â†’ 5 â†’ NULL

left = dummy, right = 1

Phase 2: Move Right by n=2

Iterationnright
Init21
112
203

âœ… Right ab 3 pe hai. Gap = 2 (dummy â†’ 1 â†’ 2 â†’ 3)

Phase 3: Move Both Until Right = NULL

IterationleftrightGap
Initdummy32
1142
2252
33NULLSTOP!

Phase 4: Delete!

left.next = left.next.next â†’ 3.next = 5 (4 skipped!)

Final: 1 â†’ 2 â†’ 3 â†’ 5 â†’ NULL ðŸŽ‰

Time & Space Complexity

â±ï¸ Time Complexity
O(n)
ðŸ’¾ Space Complexity
O(1)
ðŸ† OPTIMAL! Single pass + Constant space! Interview mein yehi approach bolna! ðŸ’¯

âš ï¸ Common Pitfalls â€” Galtiyan Mat Karo!

  1. Forgetting to Handle Head Removal:
    âŒ Jab n = list length â†’ Head delete karna hai! Bina dummy node ke crash!
    âœ… Dummy node use karo ya explicit check karo!
  2. Off-by-One Error in Pointer Positioning:
    âŒ Right ko n-1 steps move kiya â†’ Wrong node delete!
    âœ… Right ko exactly n steps aage move karo!
  3. Not Returning Updated Head:
    âŒ return head â€” Agar head delete hua toh galat reference return!
    âœ… return dummy.next â€” Always correct head milega!

ðŸ“Š Approach Comparison

Approach Time Space Key Idea
1. Brute Force (Array) O(n) O(n) Store all nodes, direct index access
2. Two Pass O(n) O(1) Count first, delete second pass
3. Recursion O(n) O(n) Unwind from end, decrement counter
4. Two Pointers â­ O(n) O(1) Gap of n, single pass, dummy node!
ðŸŽ¯ Interview Mein: Approach 4 (Two Pointers with Dummy) hi bolna! ONE PASS + O(1) space! ðŸ’¯
23

LRU Cache

Least Recently Used Cache â€” HashMap + Doubly Linked List ka Magic! ðŸ—ƒï¸

Medium Linked List Hash Table Design

ðŸ“‹ Problem Statement

Ek LRU (Least Recently Used) Cache design karo jo O(1) average time mein get aur put operations support kare.

Operations:
LRUCache(capacity) â€” Cache ko given capacity ke saath initialize karo
get(key) â€” Key ki value return karo (agar nahi hai toh -1)
put(key, value) â€” Key-value insert/update karo. Agar capacity exceed ho toh least recently used ko evict karo!
Example:
LRUCache cache = new LRUCache(2);
cache.put(1, 1); // cache: {1=1}
cache.put(2, 2); // cache: {1=1, 2=2}
cache.get(1); // returns 1, cache: {2=2, 1=1} (1 most recent)
cache.put(3, 3); // evicts key 2, cache: {1=1, 3=3}
cache.get(2); // returns -1 (not found)

ðŸ§  LRU Concept â€” Pehle Ye Samjho!

LRU (Least Recently Used) ka matlab kya hai?

  • Cache mein limited slots hote hain (capacity = C)
  • Jo item abhi-abhi use hua (get/put) â†’ Most Recently Used (MRU)
  • Jo item bahut time se use nahi hua â†’ Least Recently Used (LRU)
  • Jab naya item add karna ho aur cache FULL ho â†’ LRU ko evict (nikaalo)!
ðŸ’¡ Real Life Example: Browser tabs! Agar tumhari memory full ho jaaye, toh jo tab tumne sabse purana access kiya wo close ho jaata hai. Recently use kiye gaye tabs safe rehte hain!
WHY HASHMAP + DOUBLY LINKED LIST?
âŒ PROBLEM
Only List
get(key) = O(n) ðŸ‘Ž
Only HashMap
Recency track kaise? ðŸ¤”
âœ… SOLUTION â€” Combine Both!
HashMap
O(1) access
â†”
DLL
Recency maintain
ðŸ“

Data Structure Design â€” Internally Kya Store Hoga?

1ï¸âƒ£ Node Structure

Har cache entry ek Doubly Linked List Node hogi:

NODE STRUCTURE
Previous Node
â†’
NODE
key
val
prev
next
â†’
Next Node
âš ï¸ Important: Node mein key store karna mat bhoolna! Eviction ke time HashMap se delete karne ke liye key chahiye!

2ï¸âƒ£ HashMap

map[key] = node â†’ O(1) mein node access!

3ï¸âƒ£ Doubly Linked List with Dummy Head/Tail

DLL STRUCTURE
DUMMY
HEAD
â†”
Most Recent
ðŸŽ¯ MRU
â†”
...
â†”
Least Recent
âš ï¸ LRU
â†”
DUMMY
TAIL
ðŸ’¡ Dummy Nodes Ka Faayda:
â€¢ Empty list, single node list, head/tail update... in sab edge cases ka jhanjhat kam!
â€¢ Head ke baad = Most Recently Used
â€¢ Tail ke pehle = Least Recently Used (evict ye hoga!)
âš¡

Operations Ka Logic â€” LRU Rules!

âœ… get(key) Operation

GET OPERATION FLOW
1
get(key)
â†“
?
key in map?
No â†’
return -1
Yes â†“
node = map[key]
â†“
Move node to FRONT
â†“
return node.val
ðŸ”¥ Why Move to Front? Kyunki abhi use hua hai! Access karna matlab ye item "recently used" ban gaya!

âœ… put(key, value) Operation

PUT OPERATION FLOW
1
put(key, value)
â†“
?
key in map?
Yes â†’ KEY EXISTS
node = map[key]
node.val = value
Move to FRONT
No â†’ NEW KEY
Create new node
Add to FRONT
map[key] = node
size > capacity?
Yes â†’ EVICT LRU!
ðŸŽ¬

Visual Example â€” Step by Step!

Capacity = 2

LRU CACHE OPERATIONS - Capacity = 2
1
put(1, 10)
HEAD
â†”
1,10
â†”
TAIL
2
put(2, 20)
HEAD
â†”
2,20 MRU
â†”
1,10 LRU
â†”
TAIL
3
get(1) returns 10
HEAD
â†”
1,10 MRU
â†”
2,20 LRU
â†”
TAIL
4
put(3, 30) â†’ EVICT 2!
HEAD
â†”
3,30 MRU
â†”
1,10
â†”
TAIL
5
get(2) returns -1
Key 2 not found! âŒ
1

ðŸ† HashMap + Doubly Linked List (From Scratch!)

Helper Functions

HELPER FUNCTIONS
_remove
get prev, next
â†“
link prev to next
_add_to_front
set node pointers
â†“
insert after head
_move_to_front
remove
â†“
add to front
_pop_lru
get tail.prev
â†“
remove it
â†“
return lru
Python ðŸ† Complete LRU Cache Implementation 
# ============================================
# ðŸ† LRU CACHE â€” HashMap + Doubly Linked List
# ============================================
# Time: O(1) average for get/put
# Space: O(capacity)

class LRUCache:
    
    # ðŸ”² Node class â€” DLL ka har node
    class Node:
        __slots__ = ("key", "val", "prev", "next")
        def __init__(self, key=0, val=0):
            self.key = key   # âš ï¸ Important for eviction!
            self.val = val
            self.prev = None
            self.next = None

    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.map = {}  # key â†’ Node

        # ðŸŽ­ Dummy head/tail nodes â€” edge cases easy!
        self.head = self.Node()
        self.tail = self.Node()
        self.head.next = self.tail
        self.tail.prev = self.head

    # âœ‚ï¸ Remove node from anywhere in DLL
    def _remove(self, node):
        p, n = node.prev, node.next
        p.next = n
        n.prev = p

    # âž• Add node right after head (MRU position)
    def _add_to_front(self, node):
        node.prev = self.head
        node.next = self.head.next
        self.head.next.prev = node
        self.head.next = node

    # ðŸ”„ Move existing node to front
    def _move_to_front(self, node):
        self._remove(node)
        self._add_to_front(node)

    # ðŸ—‘ï¸ Pop LRU node (just before tail)
    def _pop_lru(self):
        lru = self.tail.prev
        self._remove(lru)
        return lru

    # ðŸ” GET operation
    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        if key not in self.map:
            return -1
        
        node = self.map[key]
        # âš¡ Abhi use hua â†’ Most Recent banao!
        self._move_to_front(node)
        return node.val

    # ðŸ“ PUT operation
    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        # ðŸ”„ Case 1: Key already exists â†’ Update!
        if key in self.map:
            node = self.map[key]
            node.val = value
            self._move_to_front(node)
            return

        # ðŸ†• Case 2: New key â†’ Insert!
        node = self.Node(key, value)
        self.map[key] = node
        self._add_to_front(node)

        # âŒ Capacity exceed? â†’ Evict LRU!
        if len(self.map) > self.cap:
            lru = self._pop_lru()
            del self.map[lru.key]  # âš ï¸ key stored in node!

Time & Space Complexity

â±ï¸ get() Time
O(1)
â±ï¸ put() Time
O(1)
ðŸ’¾ Space
O(capacity)
2

OrderedDict Approach â€” Short & Interview-Acceptable!

âš ï¸ Note: Python ka OrderedDict internally same concept use karta hai! Interview mein ye bolo but mention karo ki "from scratch" bhi bana sakte ho! ðŸ‘†
Python Approach 2: OrderedDict 
# ============================================
# ðŸ”§ LRU CACHE â€” Using OrderedDict
# ============================================
# Same O(1) complexity, but cleaner code!

from collections import OrderedDict

class LRUCache:
    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.od = OrderedDict()

    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        if key not in self.od:
            return -1
        # Move to end (most recent)
        self.od.move_to_end(key, last=False)
        return self.od[key]

    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        if key in self.od:
            self.od[key] = value
            self.od.move_to_end(key, last=False)
        else:
            self.od[key] = value
            self.od.move_to_end(key, last=False)
            if len(self.od) > self.cap:
                # Pop least recent (last=True)
                self.od.popitem(last=True)

âš ï¸ Common Pitfalls â€” Interview Mein Mat Karo!

  1. Node mein key store nahi kiya:
    âŒ Eviction ke time del map[???] â€” key nahi pata!
    âœ… Node mein key store karo: del map[lru.key]
  2. get() mein move-to-front bhool gaye:
    âŒ Access kiya but front pe nahi laye â†’ LRU galat calculate hoga!
    âœ… Har access pe _move_to_front(node) zaroor karo!
  3. put(existing) mein update + move bhool gaye:
    âŒ Value update ki but position same â†’ Recency galat!
    âœ… Update + Move both karo!
  4. Dummy nodes nahi use kiye:
    âŒ Edge cases (empty list, single node) mein crash!
    âœ… Dummy head/tail use karo â€” life easy!

ðŸ“Š Approach Comparison

Approach get() put() Space Notes
HashMap + DLL â­ O(1) O(1) O(cap) From scratch! Interview mein preferred!
OrderedDict O(1) O(1) O(cap) Clean, but mention "from scratch" bhi aata hai!
ðŸŽ¯ Interview Tip: Pehle Approach 1 (HashMap + DLL) explain karo! Ye dikhata hai ki tum data structures properly samjhte ho! ðŸ’¯

LFU Cache

Least Frequently Used Cache â€” Frequency-Based Eviction! ðŸ“Š

ðŸ“‹ Problem Statement

LFU Cache design karo jo following operations O(1) average time mein kare:

  • LFUCache(capacity) - Cache initialize karo given capacity ke saath
  • get(key) - Key ka value return karo, nahi hai to -1
  • put(key, value) - Key-value insert/update karo

Eviction Rule (Important!):

  1. Least Frequently Used item pehle nikalo
  2. Agar frequency same ho â†’ LRU within that frequency (oldest wala nikalo)
ðŸ”¥ Hard Problem â€” Amazon, Google, Facebook ka favorite! Frequency + Recency dono track karna padta hai!

ðŸ§  LFU ka Matlab Samjho (Intuition)

LRU vs LFU â€” Kya Difference Hai?

Aspect LRU Cache LFU Cache
Eviction Based On Recency (kitni der se access nahi hua) Frequency (kitni baar access hua)
Track Karte Hain Last access time Access count + recency (tie-breaker)
Example Recent = Safe Zyada used = Safe
ðŸŽ¯ Simple Analogy:
Socho tumhare paas limited shelf space hai:
â€¢ LRU: "Ye book bahut din se nahi padhi, hatao!" (recency)
â€¢ LFU: "Ye book sirf 1 baar padhi, hatao!" (frequency)
LFU Eviction Example
Key A - used 10 times
â†“
âœ… SAFE - High Frequency
Key B - used 1 time
â†“
âŒ EVICTED - Low Frequency
Even if B is more recent, A wins because frequency matters more!

âŒ Brute Force Kyu Fail Hota Hai?

Naive Approach Problems

Agar har get() pe:

  • Sab keys ki frequency scan karo
  • Minimum frequency nikalo
  • Phir LRU decide karo (tie-breaker)

âŒ Ye sab O(n) ho jaata â€” Interview reject!

ðŸ—ï¸ O(1) Design â€” Industry Standard

ðŸ’¡ Core Idea (Samjho Carefully!)

"Har frequency ka apna LRU list hota hai!"

Matlab frequency 1 ke saare keys ek list mein, frequency 2 ke alag, frequency 3 ke alag...

ðŸ“¦ Data Structures Breakdown

Three Key Data Structures
1. key_to_node
HashMap: key â†’ Node
2. freq_to_dll
HashMap: freq â†’ DLL
3. min_freq
Integer: smallest frequency
Data Structures 
# 1. key_to_node: Direct access to node
key_to_node = {
    10: Node(key=10, val=100, freq=3),
    20: Node(key=20, val=200, freq=1)
}

# 2. freq_to_dll: Frequency buckets
#    Each bucket is a DLL (LRU list)
freq_to_dll = {
    1: DLL containing [20],     # freq=1 wale keys
    3: DLL containing [10]      # freq=3 wale keys
}

# 3. min_freq: Eviction ke liye
min_freq = 1  # Sabse chhoti frequency

ðŸ”¹ Node Structure

LFU Node Structure
key
value
freq
prev
next
ðŸŽ¯ LRU se difference: LFU Node mein freq field extra hai! Ye track karta hai kitni baar access hua.

ðŸ“Š Frequency Buckets â€” Visual

LFU Cache State
Frequency = 1 â† min_freq
dummy head
â†’
key:30
â†’
dummy tail
Frequency = 2
dummy head
â†’
key:20
â†’
key:40
â†’
dummy tail
Frequency = 3
dummy head
â†’
key:10
â†’
dummy tail
ðŸŽ¯ Important Points:
â€¢ Har frequency ka apna DLL (LRU list)
â€¢ DLL mein front = most recent, tail = least recent
â€¢ min_freq directly points to eviction bucket!

âš ï¸ Golden Rule â€” Yaad Rakho!

ðŸ† Every Access = Frequency Increase

Har get() ya existing key pe put() = frequency badho!

  1. Node ko old freq DLL se hatao
  2. freq += 1
  3. New freq DLL mein front pe daalo
  4. Agar old freq empty ho gaya AND wahi min_freq tha â†’ min_freq++

ðŸ”§ _touch(node) â€” Sabse Important Function!

Ye function har access pe call hota hai â€” frequency update + recency maintain!

_touch(node) Flow
1
_touch(node) called
â†“
1
Old freq list se node hatao
â†“
?
Old freq == min_freq AND list empty?
Yes â†’
min_freq++
No â†’
Skip
â†“
3
node.freq += 1
â†“
4
New freq DLL mein add_front
â†“
5
Done - Freq updated + Recency maintained âœ…
_touch() Logic 
def _touch(self, node):
    # Step 1: Old frequency list se hatao
    old_freq = node.freq
    self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].remove(node)
    
    # Step 2: Check if we need to update min_freq
    if old_freq == self.min_freq and self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].empty():
        self.min_freq += 1  # Old bucket empty, move to next
    
    # Step 3: Frequency increase
    node.freq += 1
    new_freq = node.freq
    
    # Step 4: Add to new frequency bucket (front = most recent)
    if new_freq not in self.freq_to_dll:
        self.freq_to_dll[new_freq] = DLL()
    self.freq_to_dll[new_freq].add_front(node)

ðŸ“– GET Operation Flow

GET Operation Flow
1
get(key)
â†“
?
key in cache?
No â†’ return -1
Yes â†“
â†“
3
_touch(node) - freq++
â†“
4
return node.value

âœï¸ PUT Operation Flow

PUT Operation Flow
1
put(key, value)
â†“
?
capacity == 0? â†’ return (no-op)
â†“
?
key exists?
Yes
Update value
_touch(node)
No
cache full? â†’ EVICT LRU!
Create node (freq=1)
min_freq = 1
Add to freq=1 DLL
â†“
!
Done âœ…

âœ… Approach A: HashMap + Frequency DLLs (Optimal)

O(1) â€” Interview Standard
â±ï¸ Time: O(1) avg ðŸ’¾ Space: O(capacity)
ðŸ Python 
class LFUCache:
    """
    LFU Cache - O(1) average time for get() and put()
    Using HashMap + Frequency Buckets (each bucket is a DLL)
    """
    
    class Node:
        """Node for DLL - stores key, value, and frequency"""
        __slots__ = ("key", "val", "freq", "prev", "next")
        
        def __init__(self, key, val):
            self.key = key
            self.val = val
            self.freq = 1  # New nodes start with freq=1
            self.prev = None
            self.next = None
    
    class DLL:
        """Doubly Linked List for LRU within each frequency"""
        
        def __init__(self):
            # Dummy head and tail for easy operations
            self.head = LFUCache.Node(None, None)
            self.tail = LFUCache.Node(None, None)
            self.head.next = self.tail
            self.tail.prev = self.head
            self.size = 0
        
        def add_front(self, node):
            """Add node right after head (most recent position)"""
            node.prev = self.head
            node.next = self.head.next
            self.head.next.prev = node
            self.head.next = node
            self.size += 1
        
        def remove(self, node):
            """Remove a specific node from DLL"""
            node.prev.next = node.next
            node.next.prev = node.prev
            self.size -= 1
        
        def pop_lru(self):
            """Remove and return LRU node (just before tail)"""
            if self.size == 0:
                return None
            node = self.tail.prev  # LRU is at tail
            self.remove(node)
            return node
        
        def empty(self):
            """Check if DLL is empty"""
            return self.size == 0
    
    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.key_to_node = {}      # key -> Node
        self.freq_to_dll = {}      # freq -> DLL
        self.min_freq = 0          # Smallest frequency in cache
    
    def _touch(self, node):
        """
        Update frequency of node - THE CORE FUNCTION!
        Called on every get() and existing key put()
        """
        # Step 1: Remove from old frequency bucket
        old_freq = node.freq
        self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].remove(node)
        
        # Step 2: Update min_freq if needed
        if old_freq == self.min_freq and self.freq_to_dll[old_freq].empty():
            self.min_freq += 1
        
        # Step 3: Increment frequency
        node.freq += 1
        new_freq = node.freq
        
        # Step 4: Add to new frequency bucket
        if new_freq not in self.freq_to_dll:
            self.freq_to_dll[new_freq] = self.DLL()
        self.freq_to_dll[new_freq].add_front(node)
    
    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        """Get value by key, return -1 if not found"""
        if key not in self.key_to_node:
            return -1
        
        node = self.key_to_node[key]
        self._touch(node)  # Increase frequency!
        return node.val
    
    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        """Insert or update key-value pair"""
        if self.cap == 0:
            return
        
        # Case 1: Key exists - update value and frequency
        if key in self.key_to_node:
            node = self.key_to_node[key]
            node.val = value
            self._touch(node)
            return
        
        # Case 2: New key - check capacity first
        if len(self.key_to_node) >= self.cap:
            # Evict LFU (from min_freq bucket's tail)
            dll = self.freq_to_dll[self.min_freq]
            evict = dll.pop_lru()
            del self.key_to_node[evict.key]
        
        # Insert new node
        node = self.Node(key, value)
        self.key_to_node[key] = node
        
        # New nodes always have freq=1
        self.min_freq = 1
        if 1 not in self.freq_to_dll:
            self.freq_to_dll[1] = self.DLL()
        self.freq_to_dll[1].add_front(node)

ðŸ”„ Dry Run Example

Step-by-Step 
# Capacity = 2

put(1, 10)  # cache: {1:10}, freq_to_dll: {1: [1]}
            # min_freq = 1

put(2, 20)  # cache: {1:10, 2:20}, freq_to_dll: {1: [2,1]}
            # min_freq = 1

get(1)      # freq(1) = 2, move 1 from freq=1 to freq=2
            # freq_to_dll: {1: [2], 2: [1]}
            # min_freq = 1 (freq=1 bucket not empty)

put(3, 30)  # capacity full! Evict from min_freq=1
            # Key 2 evicted (LRU in freq=1)
            # Insert key 3 with freq=1
            # freq_to_dll: {1: [3], 2: [1]}
            # min_freq = 1

# Final cache: {1:10, 3:30}
# Key 2 was evicted because:
# - Key 1 had freq=2
# - Key 2 had freq=1 (least frequently used)

ðŸ“¦ Approach B: Heap / Priority Queue

O(log n) â€” Sub-optimal

âš ï¸ Important Disclaimer

  • Simpler to implement
  • But NOT strict O(1) â€” O(log n)
  • Interview mein: "Acceptable but sub-optimal"
â±ï¸ Time: O(log n) ðŸ’¾ Space: O(n) + stale entries

ðŸ’¡ Core Idea

Har key ke saath 3 cheezein track karo:

  1. frequency â€” kitni baar access hui
  2. time / counter â€” recency tie-breaker
  3. key

Heap mein store: (freq, time, key)
Python ka heapq = min-heap, so pehle lowest freq, phir oldest time!

âš ï¸ Major Problem: Heap Update

Python heap update support nahi karta!

So jab frequency badhti hai:

  • Hum new entry push kar dete hain
  • Old heap entry stale ho jaati hai

Solution â†’ Lazy Deletion:

Eviction ke time: pop karo, check karo valid hai ya nahi, nahi to ignore & pop next!

ðŸ Python 
import heapq

class LFUCache:
    """
    LFU Cache - Heap-based approach
    O(log n) time, simpler but sub-optimal
    Uses lazy deletion for stale entries
    """
    
    def __init__(self, capacity: int):
        self.cap = capacity
        self.time = 0                  # Global timestamp
        self.heap = []                 # (freq, time, key)
        self.key_to_val_freq = {}      # key -> [value, freq]
    
    def get(self, key: int) -> int:
        if key not in self.key_to_val_freq:
            return -1
        
        self.time += 1
        val, freq = self.key_to_val_freq[key]
        
        # Increase frequency
        freq += 1
        self.key_to_val_freq[key] = [val, freq]
        
        # Push new entry (old one becomes stale)
        heapq.heappush(self.heap, (freq, self.time, key))
        
        return val
    
    def put(self, key: int, value: int) -> None:
        if self.cap == 0:
            return
        
        self.time += 1
        
        # Case 1: Key exists - update
        if key in self.key_to_val_freq:
            _, freq = self.key_to_val_freq[key]
            freq += 1
            self.key_to_val_freq[key] = [value, freq]
            heapq.heappush(self.heap, (freq, self.time, key))
            return
        
        # Case 2: New key - check capacity
        if len(self.key_to_val_freq) >= self.cap:
            # Evict LFU using lazy deletion
            while self.heap:
                freq, t, k = heapq.heappop(self.heap)
                
                # Check if this entry is still valid
                if k in self.key_to_val_freq:
                    cur_val, cur_freq = self.key_to_val_freq[k]
                    
                    # Valid only if freq matches current freq
                    if cur_freq == freq:
                        del self.key_to_val_freq[k]
                        break
                    # Else: stale entry, skip and pop next
        
        # Insert new key
        self.key_to_val_freq[key] = [value, 1]
        heapq.heappush(self.heap, (1, self.time, key))

ðŸ”„ Dry Run (Quick)

Execution 
# Capacity = 2

put(1, 10)  # heap: [(1, 1, 1)], map: {1: [10, 1]}
put(2, 20)  # heap: [(1, 1, 1), (1, 2, 2)], map: {1: [10, 1], 2: [20, 1]}

get(1)      # freq(1) = 2
            # heap: [(1, 1, 1), (1, 2, 2), (2, 3, 1)]  # old entry stale
            # map: {1: [10, 2], 2: [20, 1]}

put(3, 30)  # capacity full! Pop from heap:
            # Pop (1, 1, 1) - stale! (current freq of key 1 is 2)
            # Pop (1, 2, 2) - valid! freq matches, evict key 2
            # Insert key 3
            # Final: map: {1: [10, 2], 3: [30, 1]}

â±ï¸ Complexity Reality Check

Operation Approach A (Freq DLL) Approach B (Heap)
get() O(1) O(log n)
put() O(1) O(log n)
Space O(capacity) O(n) + stale
Stale Entries No Yes
âš ï¸ Heap Warning: Heap can grow beyond capacity because of stale entries!

âš–ï¸ Approach Comparison â€” Interview Ready!

Feature Approach A (Freq DLL) â­ Approach B (Heap)
Time Complexity O(1) strict O(log n)
Code Complexity Complex Simple
Stale Entries No Yes
Interview Score â­â­â­â­â­ â­â­â­
Real Systems Redis-like Rare

ðŸŽ¯ When to Use Heap Approach?

  • Quick implementation needed
  • Low constraints / small data
  • Interviewer says: "O(log n) is fine"
  • Whiteboard round with limited time

ðŸ†š LRU vs LFU â€” Complete Comparison

Aspect LRU Cache LFU Cache
Eviction Logic Least Recently Used Least Frequently Used
Track Kya Karte Hain Recency (last access time) Frequency + Recency (tie-breaker)
Data Structures HashMap + 1 DLL HashMap + Multiple DLLs (per freq)
Extra Tracking - min_freq variable
Complexity Simpler More complex
Use Case Browser cache, OS page cache CDN, Database query cache
LRU Cache
HashMap + 1 DLL
Evict: Tail of DLL
LFU Cache
HashMap + N DLLs (by freq)
Evict: Tail of min_freq DLL

âœ¨ Interview Gold Points

ðŸ”¥ Key Points to Remember

  • LFU = Frequency Buckets + LRU inside each bucket
  • min_freq is mandatory for O(1) eviction
  • Every access = frequency increase
  • Eviction always from min_freq bucket's tail
  • DLL needed to break frequency ties (LRU within same freq)
  • New nodes always start with freq=1, so min_freq=1 after insert
ðŸŽ¯ One-liner Takeaway (Reel / Interview):

"LFU Cache is HashMap + Frequency Buckets, where each bucket is an LRU list, and min_freq tells you exactly whom to evict in O(1)."

âš ï¸ Common Pitfalls â€” Interview Mein Mat Karo!

  1. min_freq update bhool gaye:
    âŒ Old freq bucket empty hua but min_freq same â†’ Wrong eviction!
    âœ… Jab old freq bucket empty ho AND wahi min_freq tha â†’ min_freq++
  2. New insert pe min_freq = 1 nahi kiya:
    âŒ New node insert kiya but min_freq purana â†’ Galat eviction!
    âœ… Har new insert pe min_freq = 1 (kyunki new node ki freq=1)
  3. Node mein freq store nahi kiya:
    âŒ _touch() mein old freq nahi pata!
    âœ… Node structure mein freq field rakho
  4. Same key update pe _touch bhool gaye:
    âŒ Value update ki but frequency same â†’ Galat LFU behavior!
    âœ… Existing key pe put() bhi _touch() call karo

ðŸ“Š Approach Comparison

Approach get() put() Space Notes
HashMap + Freq DLLs â­ O(1) O(1) O(cap) Industry standard! Interview mein ye bolo!
Heap / Priority Queue O(log n) O(log n) O(n)+stale Simpler, but sub-optimal with lazy deletion
ðŸŽ¯ Interview Tip: Pehle Approach A (HashMap + Frequency DLLs) explain karo! Ye dikhata hai ki tum complex data structures properly samjhte ho! ðŸ’¯
ðŸ“…

Intervals

Overlapping ranges, merging, and scheduling â€” Google's favorite topic! ðŸ”¥

1 Problem

26. Merge Intervals ðŸ”¥ GOOGLE

Overlapping intervals ko merge karo â€” Sorting + Greedy ka classic! ðŸ“…

MEDIUM

ðŸ“‹ Problem Statement

Given an array of intervals where intervals[i] = [start_i, end_i], merge all overlapping intervals, and return an array of the non-overlapping intervals that cover all the intervals in the input.

Example 1:
Input: intervals = [[1,3],[2,6],[8,10],[15,18]]
Output: [[1,6],[8,10],[15,18]]
Explanation: [1,3] and [2,6] overlap â†’ merge into [1,6]
Example 2:
Input: intervals = [[1,4],[4,5]]
Output: [[1,5]]
Explanation: [1,4] and [4,5] touch at 4 â†’ merge into [1,5]
Example 3:
Input: intervals = [[1,4],[0,4]]
Output: [[0,4]]
Explanation: [0,4] contains [1,4] â†’ merge into [0,4]
Constraints:
  • 1 â‰¤ intervals.length â‰¤ 10â´
  • intervals[i].length == 2
  • 0 â‰¤ start_i â‰¤ end_i â‰¤ 10â´

ðŸ§  Problem Ka Real Intuition â€” Socho Meeting Rooms!

ðŸŽ¯ Real Life Example: Socho tumhare paas meetings ki list hai:

  • Meeting A: 9:00 - 11:00
  • Meeting B: 10:00 - 12:00 (overlaps with A!)
  • Meeting C: 14:00 - 16:00 (separate)

Tumhe batana hai: "Actually kitne time slots blocked hain?"
â†’ A aur B overlap karti hain, toh ek hi slot: 9:00-12:00
â†’ C alag hai: 14:00-16:00

ðŸ  Real Life Applications
  • ðŸ“… Calendar merging: Google Calendar me overlapping events merge karna
  • ðŸŽ® Game development: Collision detection ranges merge karna
  • ðŸ“Š Data analysis: Time series data ko consolidate karna
  • ðŸš— Traffic systems: Overlapping road blocks ko combine karna

ðŸ”‘ Why Sorting is the Key?

ðŸ’¡ Bina sorting ke problem mushkil hai!

Agar intervals random order me hain:
[[8,10], [1,3], [2,6], [15,18]]

Tumhe har interval ke liye poora list check karna padega â†’ O(nÂ²)

But agar sort kar lo by start time:
[[1,3], [2,6], [8,10], [15,18]]

Ab sirf adjacent intervals hi overlap kar sakte hain! Linear scan â†’ O(n)

ðŸ“Š Sorting Makes Life Easy!
âŒ Unsorted - O(nÂ²)
[8,10]
[1,3]
[2,6]
[15,18]

Every pair needs checking! ðŸ¢

âœ… Sorted - O(n)
[1,3]
[2,6]
[8,10]
[15,18]

Only check adjacent! âš¡

ðŸ¤ When Do Two Intervals Overlap?

Do intervals [a, b] aur [c, d] (where a â‰¤ c after sorting):

  • âœ… Overlap: b >= c (first interval ka end >= second ka start)
  • âŒ No Overlap: b < c (gap hai beech me)
ðŸ” Overlap Cases Explained
Case 1: Partial Overlap
A: 1â”â”â”â”3
B: 2â”â”â”â”â”â”6
â†’ Merged: [1, 6]
Case 2: One Contains Other
A: 1â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”6
B: 2â”â”4
â†’ Merged: [1, 6]
Case 3: Touch at Edge
A: 1â”â”â”4
B: 4â”â”5
â†’ Merged: [1, 5]
Case 4: No Overlap (Gap)
A: 1â”3
B: 8â”â”10
â†’ Both stay separate

âœ… Approach A: Sort + Linear Merge (Optimal)

O(n log n) O(n)

ðŸ’¡ Algorithm Steps

  1. Sort intervals by start time
  2. Initialize result with first interval
  3. Iterate through remaining intervals:
    • If overlap â†’ extend the last interval's end
    • If no overlap â†’ add new interval to result
  4. Return merged result
ðŸ”„ Merge Algorithm Flow
Sort intervals
â†’
Initialize result
â†’
For each interval
â†“
Overlap with last?
YES â†’ Extend last.end
NO â†’ Add new interval
â†“
Return merged result

ðŸ“º Visual Dry Run

ðŸŽ¬ Step-by-Step Merge
1
Start with [1,3]
result = [[1,3]]
2
Check [2,6] â†’ 2 â‰¤ 3? YES! Overlap!
Extend: [1, max(3,6)] = [1,6] â†’ result = [[1,6]]
3
Check [8,10] â†’ 8 â‰¤ 6? NO! Gap!
Add new â†’ result = [[1,6], [8,10]]
4
Check [15,18] â†’ 15 â‰¤ 10? NO! Gap!
Add new â†’ result = [[1,6], [8,10], [15,18]] âœ…
ðŸ” Detailed Dry Run Table
Step Current Last in Result Overlap? Action Result
Init [1,3] - - Add to result [[1,3]]
1 [2,6] [1,3] âœ… 2 â‰¤ 3 Extend to [1,6] [[1,6]]
2 [8,10] [1,6] âŒ 8 > 6 Add [8,10] [[1,6],[8,10]]
3 [15,18] [8,10] âŒ 15 > 10 Add [15,18] [[1,6],[8,10],[15,18]]
Python - Approach A (Sort + Merge) 
class Solution:
    def merge(self, intervals: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        """
        Merge Overlapping Intervals - Google Favorite!
        
        Approach: Sort by start time, then linear merge
        
        Key Insight:
        - After sorting, only adjacent intervals can overlap
        - Two intervals [a,b] and [c,d] overlap if b >= c
        
        Time: O(n log n) - sorting dominates
        Space: O(n) - for result array
        """
        
        # Edge case: empty or single interval
        if len(intervals) <= 1:
            return intervals
        
        # Step 1: Sort by start time
        # This ensures overlapping intervals are adjacent
        intervals.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
        
        # Step 2: Initialize result with first interval
        result = [intervals[0]]
        
        # Step 3: Process each interval
        for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
            current = intervals[i]
            last = result[-1]  # Last interval in result
            
            # Check for overlap: current.start <= last.end
            if current[0] <= last[1]:
                # Overlap found! Extend the last interval
                # Take max of both ends to cover all cases:
                # - Partial overlap: [1,3], [2,6] â†’ [1,6]
                # - One contains other: [1,6], [2,4] â†’ [1,6]
                last[1] = max(last[1], current[1])
            else:
                # No overlap - add as new interval
                result.append(current)
        
        return result


# ============ USAGE EXAMPLES ============
if __name__ == "__main__":
    sol = Solution()
    
    # Example 1: Partial overlap
    print(sol.merge([[1,3],[2,6],[8,10],[15,18]]))
    # Output: [[1,6],[8,10],[15,18]]
    
    # Example 2: Touch at edge
    print(sol.merge([[1,4],[4,5]]))
    # Output: [[1,5]]
    
    # Example 3: One contains other
    print(sol.merge([[1,4],[2,3]]))
    # Output: [[1,4]]

ðŸ“š Approach B: Stack-Based Merge

O(n log n) O(n)

ðŸ’¡ Stack Approach Idea

Same logic, but stack use karo result ke liye:

  • Sort intervals
  • Push first interval to stack
  • For each interval: peek stack top, merge or push

Same complexity, different style â€” useful if interviewer asks for variation!

Python - Approach B (Stack) 
class Solution:
    def merge(self, intervals: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        """
        Stack-based approach for merging intervals.
        
        Same logic as Approach A, but uses stack explicitly.
        Useful for interview variation questions.
        """
        
        if not intervals:
            return []
        
        # Sort by start time
        intervals.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
        
        # Use list as stack
        stack = [intervals[0]]
        
        for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
            top = stack[-1]  # Peek stack top
            current = intervals[i]
            
            if current[0] <= top[1]:
                # Overlap - modify top of stack
                stack[-1][1] = max(top[1], current[1])
            else:
                # No overlap - push new interval
                stack.append(current)
        
        return stack

ðŸ”§ Approach C: In-Place Merge (Space Optimized)

O(n log n) O(1) extra

ðŸ’¡ In-Place Idea

Extra result array mat banao! Input array ko hi modify karo:

  • Use a write pointer j
  • Merge in place and track valid length
  • Return only the merged portion

âš ï¸ Note: Sorting still takes O(n) space internally in Python, but this saves the extra result array!

Python - Approach C (In-Place) 
class Solution:
    def merge(self, intervals: List[List[int]]) -> List[List[int]]:
        """
        In-place merge - no extra result array needed.
        
        Uses write pointer to overwrite input array.
        Returns slice of original array.
        
        Space: O(1) extra (ignoring sort's internal space)
        """
        
        if len(intervals) <= 1:
            return intervals
        
        # Sort in place
        intervals.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])
        
        # j = write pointer (points to last merged interval)
        j = 0
        
        for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
            # If current overlaps with intervals[j]
            if intervals[i][0] <= intervals[j][1]:
                # Merge: extend intervals[j]
                intervals[j][1] = max(intervals[j][1], intervals[i][1])
            else:
                # No overlap: move write pointer and copy
                j += 1
                intervals[j] = intervals[i]
        
        # Return merged portion (0 to j inclusive)
        return intervals[:j + 1]

ðŸŽ¤ Google Follow-up Questions

ðŸ”¥ Google loves these follow-ups:

  • ðŸ“Œ "What if intervals are coming as a stream?"
    â†’ Use a balanced BST (like TreeMap) to maintain sorted order, O(log n) per insert
  • ðŸ“Œ "Can you handle very large data that doesn't fit in memory?"
    â†’ External merge sort + streaming merge
  • ðŸ“Œ "What if you need to support insert AND query?"
    â†’ Interval Tree data structure
  • ðŸ“Œ "What if you need to find overlapping intervals for a given query?"
    â†’ Interval Tree or Segment Tree

ðŸ”— Related Interval Problems (Google Favorites)

Problem Difficulty Key Idea
Insert Interval Medium Insert new interval and merge
Non-overlapping Intervals Medium Min removals to make non-overlapping
Meeting Rooms Easy Can attend all meetings?
Meeting Rooms II Medium Min meeting rooms needed
Employee Free Time Hard Find free slots across schedules

âš ï¸ Common Pitfalls â€” Avoid These!

âŒ Pitfall 1: Forgetting to sort
# WRONG!
def merge(self, intervals):
    result = [intervals[0]]
    for i in range(1, len(intervals)):
        # Without sorting, this logic fails!
        # [[8,10], [1,3], [2,6]] â†’ wrong answer
âŒ Pitfall 2: Using < instead of <=
# WRONG!
if current[0] < last[1]:  # Misses edge case!
    # [[1,4], [4,5]] should merge to [[1,5]]
    # But 4 < 4 is False, so they won't merge!

Fix: Use <= to handle touching intervals!

âŒ Pitfall 3: Not using max() for end
# WRONG!
last[1] = current[1]  # Overwrites without checking!
# [[1,6], [2,4]] â†’ becomes [[1,4]] instead of [[1,6]]

Fix: Always use max(last[1], current[1])

ðŸ“Š Complexity Summary

Approach Time Space Notes
Sort + Merge â­ O(n log n) O(n) Best for interviews! Clean and readable
Stack-Based O(n log n) O(n) Same complexity, different style
In-Place O(n log n) O(1)* *Ignoring sort's internal space

* Sorting is the bottleneck - O(n log n). The merge step is O(n).

ðŸ”¥ Google Interview One-liner

"Sort intervals by start time, then linearly merge adjacent overlapping intervals by extending the end point â€” the key insight is that after sorting, only adjacent intervals can possibly overlap!"
